Question 10 For the circuit shown, if [latex]\mathrm{i}=\sin 1000 t[/latex], the instantaneous value of the Thevenin's equivalent voltage (in Volts) across the terminals a-b at time [latex]\mathrm{t}=5 \mathrm{~ms}[/latex] is ___ (Round off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
By source transformation, the circuit become Apply KVL in loop, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& (10+j 1)+4 i_{x}-(10+j 10+10-j 10) i_{x}=0 \\
& 10+\mathrm{j} 10+4 \mathrm{i}_{x}-20 \mathrm{i}_{x}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{x}}=0.884 \angle 45^{\circ} \mathrm{A} \\
& \text { Now, } \quad \mathrm{V}_{\text {Th }}=\mathrm{i}_{x}(10-\mathrm{j10}) \\
& =0.884 \angle 45^{\circ} \times 14.142 \angle-45^{\circ} \\
& =12.5 \angle 0^{\circ} \mathrm{V} \\
& \therefore \quad \mathrm{V}_{\text {Th }}=12.5 \sin 1000 \mathrm{t} \\
& \text { At } \quad \mathrm{t}=5 \mathrm{msec} \\
& \mathrm{V}_{\text {Th }}=12.5 \times \sin \left(\frac{5 \times 180^{\circ}}{\pi}\right) \\
& =-11.986 \mathrm{~V}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

solution: Apply kVL : [latex]75-(2k)I-0.5V_1=0 [/latex]   ...(1) From circuit: [latex] V_1=(8k)I[/latex] [latex]I=\frac{V_1}{8k} [/latex]   ...(2) From equation (1) & (2) [latex] 75-(2k) \times \frac{V}{8k}-0.5V_1=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow V_1=100V[/latex]

Question 15 The network shown below has a resonant frequency of 150 kHz and a bandwidth of
600 Hz. The Q-factor of the network is __________. (round off to nearest integer)

question:
Question 16 An inductor having a Q-factor of 60 is connected in series with a capacitor having a Q-factor of 240. The overall Q-factor of the circuit is ________. (round off to nearest
integer)
solution: We have, overall Q-factor of given circuit is, [latex] Q=\frac{Q_LQ_C}{Q_L+Q_C}=\frac{60 \times 240}{60+240}=48 [/latex]

question:
Question 17 In the circuit shown below, a three-phase star-connected unbalanced load is connected
to a balanced three-phase supply of [latex]100\sqrt{3}[/latex] with phase sequence [latex]ABC[/latex]. The star
connected load has [latex]Z_A=10\Omega[/latex] and [latex]Z_B=20\angle 60^{\circ}[/latex]. The value of [latex]Z_C[/latex] in [latex]\Omega[/latex], for which
the voltage difference across the nodes [latex]n[/latex]and [latex]n'[/latex] is zero, is
solution: Given: n & n' are at same potential, therefore, [latex] I_{nn'}=0[/latex] [latex] I_{A}+I_{B}+I_{C}=0[/latex] [latex] \frac{E_A}{Z_A}+\frac{E_B}{Z_B}+\frac{E_C}{Z_C}=0[/latex] where , [latex] E_A=100\angle 0^{\circ}V \text{ and }Z_A=10\Omega  [/latex] [latex] E_B=100\angle -120^{\circ}V \text{ and }Z_B=20\angle 60^{\circ}  [/latex] [latex] E_C=100\angle 120^{\circ}V \text{ and }Z_C=?  [/latex] [latex] \therefore \frac{100\angle 0^{\circ}}{10}+\frac{100\angle -120^{\circ}}{20\angle 60^{\circ} }+\frac{100\angle 120^{\circ}}{Z_C}=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow Z_C=20\angle -60^{\circ} \Omega [/latex]

question: Question 18 The transfer function of a real system, [latex]H(s)[/latex], is given as: [latex]H(s)=\frac{As+B}{s^2+Cs+D}[/latex] where A, B, C and D are positive constants. This system cannot operate as
solution:
Put [latex] s=0, H(0)=\frac{A \times 0+B}{0+C \times 0+D}=\frac{B}{D}[/latex] So, the system pass low frequency component.
Put [latex] s=\infty , H(\infty )=0[/latex] For high pass filter, high frequency component
should be non zero. Hence this system cannot
be operated as high pass filter.

question: Question 19 A [latex]\text{100 Hz}[/latex] square wave, switching between [latex]\text{0 V}[/latex] and [latex]\text{5 V}[/latex], is applied to a [latex]\text{CR}[/latex] high-pass filter circuit as shown. The output voltage waveform across the resistor is [latex]\text{6.2 V}[/latex] peak-to-peak. If the resistance R is [latex]\text{820 $\Omega$}[/latex], then the value C is ______________[latex]\mu F[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{0}&=v_{i}-v_{c}\\ \text{For }1^{\text {st }}\text{ half cycle}, \quad v_{0}&=5-v_{c} \\ \text{For }2^{\text {nd }}\text{ half cycle}, \quad v_{0}&=-v_{c}\\ v_{p-p} &=\left(5-V_{c \;\min}\right)-\left(-V_{c}\; \max \right) \\ 6.2 &=5+V_{c \;\max }-V_{c \;\min} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{c \max }-V_{c \;\min } &=1.2 \ldots(\alpha) \end{aligned}[/latex] For first half cycle i.e. [latex]0 \lt t \lt \frac{T}{2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{c}\left(0^{+}\right) &=v_{c}(0)=v_{c}\left(0^{-}\right)=v_{c} \min \\ v_{c}(\infty) &=5 \mathrm{~V} \\ \therefore \qquad\qquad v_{c}(t) &=v_{c}(\infty)+\left[v_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)-v_{c}(\infty)\right] e^{-t / \tau} \\ v_{c}(t) &=5+\left[V_{c m i n}-5\right] e^{-t / 2 \tau}=V_{c m a x} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{c} \max &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+V_{c m i n} e^{-T / 2 \tau} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] For \frac{T}{2} \lt t \lt T[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{c}(t) &=v_{c}\left(\frac{T}{2}\right) e^{-t(t-T / 2) \tau} \\ \therefore\qquad v_{c}(t) &=V_{c m a x} e^{-(t-T / 2) \tau} \\ \text{at } t =T,\qquad \qquad v_{c} &=V_{c} \mathrm{~min} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad V_{C \mathrm{~min}} &=V_{C \max } e^{-T / 2 \tau}\\ \text { As } \quad V_{c \text { max }}-V_{c \text { min }}&=1.2 \qquad \qquad [\text { From }(\alpha)]\\ \therefore \quad V_{\text {cmax }}-V_{c \max } e^{-T / 2 t} &=1.2 \\ V_{c} \max &=\frac{1.2}{1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{c} \max &=\frac{1.2}{1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}}=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+V_{c \min } e^{-2 \tau} \end{aligned}[/latex] From (ii), [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{c \max } &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+\left(V_{c m a x} e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right) e^{-T / 2 \tau} \\ V_{c \max } &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+V_{c \max } e^{-T / \tau} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad V_{c \max }\left[1-e^{-T / \tau}\right] &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right] \\ V_{c} \max &=\frac{5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]}{\left[1+e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using equation (iii) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1.2}{1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}} &=\frac{5}{1+e^{-T / 2 \tau}} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 1.2+1.2 e^{-T / 2 \tau} &=5-5 e^{-\pi / 2 t} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 6.2 e^{-T / 2 \tau} &=3.8 \\ e^{-T / 2 \tau} &=\frac{3.8}{6.2}=0.6129 \\ \frac{T}{2 \tau} &=0.4895\\ \text { as }\qquad \qquad T&=\frac{1}{f}=\frac{1}{100} \mathrm{sec}\\ \text { and }\qquad \qquad \tau & =R C=820 \mathrm{C} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \frac{1}{(100)(2)(820) C} & =0.4895 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad C & =12.46 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 An air-core radio-frequency transformer as shown has a primary winding and a secondary winding. The mutual inductance M between the windings of the transformer is ____________ [latex]\mu H[/latex].(Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{1}&=\frac{5}{22}(p-p) \\ V_{0}&=j \omega M I_{1}=7.3=\left(2 \pi \times 10 \times 10^{3}\right) \times M \times\left(\frac{5}{22}\right) \\ M&=51.10 \mu \mathrm{H} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 21 In the given circuit, for maximum power to be delivered to [latex]R_{L}[/latex], its value should be ______________ [latex]\Omega[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]=\frac{-j}{\omega C}=\frac{-j}{1000 \times 0.5 \times 10^{-3}}=-j 2 \Omega[/latex] [latex] Z_{\text {in }}=2 \| j 2=\frac{j 4}{2+j 2}=\frac{j 2}{1+j 1}[/latex] For maximum power transfer, [latex] R_{L}=\left|Z_{\mathrm{TH}}\right|=\frac{2}{\sqrt{2}}=\sqrt{2}=1.414 \Omega[/latex]

question: Question 22 A three-phase balanced voltage is applied to the load shown. The phase sequence is [latex]\text{RYB}[/latex]. The ratio [latex]\frac{\left | I_{B} \right |}{|I_{R}|}[/latex] is ____________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{R} &=\frac{V_{R B}}{-j 10}=\frac{V_{L} \angle-60^{\circ}}{-j 10}=\frac{V_{L}}{10} \angle 30^{\circ} \\ I_{Y} &=\frac{V_{Y B}}{j 10}=\frac{V_{L} \angle-120^{\circ}}{-j 10}=\frac{V_{L}}{10} \angle 150^{\circ} \\ \text { and }\qquad \qquad I_{B}&=-\left(I_{R}+I_{Y}\right)=\frac{V_{L}}{10} \angle-90^{\circ} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \left|\frac{I_{B}}{I_{R}}\right|&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 23 The input impedance, [latex]Z_{in}\left ( s \right )[/latex] for the network shown is
solution: Circuit in s-domain, [latex]\begin{aligned} -S I_{1}+(4 s+5) I_{2} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad I_{2} &=\frac{s}{4 s+5} I_{1} \\ V_{1} &=(4+6 s) I_{1}-\frac{s^{2}}{4 s+5} I_{1} \\ \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}} &=\frac{(4+6 s)(4 s+5)-s^{2}}{4 s+5} \\ &=\frac{24 s^{2}+30 s+16 s+20-s^{2}}{4 s+5} \\ Z_{\text {in }} &=\frac{23 s^{2}+46 s+20}{4 s+5} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 In the circuit, switch 'S' is in the closed position for a very long time. If the switch is opened at time [latex]t = 0[/latex], then in [latex]i_{L} (t)[/latex] amperes, for [latex]t\geq0[/latex] is
solution: At [latex]t = 0^-[/latex] [latex] i_{L}\left(0^{-}\right)=\frac{10}{1}=10 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] For[latex] t > 0 [/latex] At [latex]t = \infty [/latex] [latex] i(\infty)=\frac{40}{5}=8 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] [latex] R_{\text{eq}}:[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{\mathrm{eq}} &=5 \Omega \\ \tau &=\frac{L}{R_{\mathrm{eq}}}=\frac{0.5}{5}=0.1 \mathrm{sec} \\ i(t) &=8+[10-8] e^{-t / 0.1} \\ &=8+2 e^{-10 t} \mathrm{~A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 25 A signal generator having a source resistance of [latex]50\:\Omega[/latex] is set to generate a [latex]\text{1 kHz}[/latex] sinewave. Open circuit terminal voltage is [latex]\text{10 V}[/latex] peak-to-peak. Connecting a capacitor across the terminals reduces the voltage to [latex]\text{8 V}[/latex] peak-to-peak. The value of this capacitor is _____________[latex]\mu F[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{0}(j \omega)}{V_{i}(j \omega)} &=\frac{1}{1+j \omega R C} \\ \frac{8}{10} \angle \theta &=\frac{1}{1+j \omega R C} \\ 1+j \omega R C &=1.25 \angle \theta \\ \omega R C &=\sqrt{1.25^{2}-1^{2}} \\ \omega R C &=0.75 \\ C &=\frac{0.75}{2000 \pi \times 50}=2.38 \mu\mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 In the given circuit, for voltage [latex]V_y[/latex] to be zero, the value of [latex]\beta[/latex] should be _________. (Round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{x}-6}{1}+\frac{V_{x}}{4}+\frac{V_{x}-V_{y}}{2} & =0 \\ 4 V_{x}-24+V_{x}+2 V_{x}-2 V_{y} & =0 \\ 7 V_{x}-2 V_{y} & =24 \\ \text { If } V_{y}=0 \qquad\qquad 7 V_{x} & =24 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad\qquad V_{x} & =\frac{24}{7} \\ \Rightarrow\qquad\qquad \frac{V_{y}-V_{x}}{2}+\frac{V_{y}-\beta V_{x}}{3} & =2 \\ 3 V_{y}-3 V_{x}+2 V_{y}-2 \beta V_{x} & =12 \\ 5 V_{y}-(3+2 \beta) V_{x} & =12 \\ V_{y} & =0\\ -(3+2 \beta) \frac{24}{7} &=12 \\ (3+2 \beta) &=\frac{-7}{2} \\ 2 \beta &=\frac{-7}{2}-3=\frac{-7-6}{2}=\frac{-13}{2} \\ \beta &=\frac{-13}{4}=-3.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 27 In the given circuit, the value of capacitor C that makes current [latex]I=0[/latex]
 is _________ [latex]\mu F[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{L} &=(j 5) \|\left(j 5-j X_{c}\right) \\ \frac{(j 5)\left(j 5-j X_{c}\right)}{j 5+j 5-j X_{c}} &=\infty \\ j 5+j-j X_{c} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad j X_{c} &=j 10 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad X_{c} &=10 \Omega \\ X_{c} &=\frac{1}{\omega C}=10 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad C&=\frac{1}{10 \times 5 \times 10^{3}} \\ C &=\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{4}} \times \frac{10^{2}}{10^{2}}=\frac{10^{2}}{5 \times 10^{6}}=20 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 For the network shown, the equivalent Thevenin voltage and Thevenin impedance as seen across terminals 'ab' is
solution: Given circuit can be resolved as shown below, [latex] V_{T H}=15+50=65 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{x} &=2+3+10=15 \mathrm{~V} \\ R_{\mathrm{TH}} &=\frac{V_{x}}{1}=15 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 29 A benchtop dc power supply acts as an ideal 4 A current source as long as its terminal
voltage is below 10 V. Beyond this point, it begins to behave as an ideal 10 V voltage
source for all load currents going down to 0 A. When connected to an ideal rheostat,
find the load resistance value at which maximum power is transferred, and the corresponding
load voltage and current.
solution:
Maximum power transistor of VI product is maximum. If draw the the curve, it intersect
(10, 4) that will give maximum power.
The terminal voltage is 10 V (Load voltage) and current is 4 A (Load current).
Load resistance is [latex]\frac{10}{4}=2.5\Omega[/latex]

.

question:
Question 30 The Thevenin equivalent voltage, [latex]V_{TH}[/latex], in V (rounded off to 2 decimal places) of the network
shown below, is _______ .
solution: Only voltage source 4V is there and current source 5A is open circuited From the above circuit, [latex]V_{TH1}=4V[/latex] Case-II: Only current source 5A is there and voltage source 4V is short circuited. From the above circuit, [latex]V_{TH2}=2 \times 5=10V[/latex] By applying superposition theorem, [latex]V_{TH}=V_{TH1}+V_{TH2}=10+4=14V[/latex]

question:
Question 31 [latex]x_R\; and \; x_A[/latex] are, respectively, the rms and average values of [latex]x(t) = x(t - T)[/latex], and similarly,
[latex]y_R\; and \; y_A[/latex] are, respectively, the rms and average values of [latex]y(t) = kx(t). k, \;T[/latex] are
independent of t. Which of the following is true?
solution:
Given that, [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=x(t-T) \; \text{  i.e. periodic signal}\\ \text{Average of } x(t)&=x_{A}\\ \text{Rms of  }x(t)&=x_{R} \\ \text{Average of }y(t)&=y_{A}\\ \text{Rms of } y(t)&=y_{R} \\ y(t)&=k_{x}(t_{0}) \; \; ....(i) \\ &\text{Using equation(i),}\\ \text{Average of }y(t)&=k 
 \times \text{ Average of }x(t) \\ y_{A}&=kx_{A}\\ \text{Power of }y(t)&=|k|^{2}\text{ Power of }x(t) \\ Rms^{2} \text{ of } y(t)&=|k|^{2}\; Rms^{2}\text{ of }x(t) \\ y_{R}^{2}=|k|^{2}\cdot x_{R}^{2} \\ y_{R}=|k|x_{R}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 The current flowing in the circuit shown below in amperes is _____
solution: By Millman'e theorem, [latex]E=\frac{\frac{200}{50}+\frac{160}{40}-\frac{100}{25}-\frac{80}{20}}{\frac{1}{50}+\frac{1}{40}+\frac{1}{25}+\frac{1}{20}}=0V [/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{R}=\frac{1}{50}+\frac{1}{40}+\frac{1}{25}+\frac{1}{20} [/latex] Simplified circuit, [latex]\therefore \;\;I=0A[/latex]

question: Question 33 A 0.1[latex]\mu F[/latex] capacitor charged to 100 V is discharged through a 1 [latex]k\Omega[/latex] resistor. The time in ms (round off to two decimal places) required for the voltage across the capacitor to drop to 1V is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_c(t)&=V_0e^{-t/\tau } \\ V_0&=100V \\ \tau &=RC=(10^3)(10^{-7}) \\ &=10^{-4}sec \\ \therefore \;v_c(t)&=100e^{-10^4 t }V \end{aligned}[/latex] Let the time required by the voltage across the capacitor to drop to 1 V is [latex]t_1, [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; v_c(t_1)&=100e^{-10^4t_1} \\ \text{But, }  v_c(t_1)&=0  \\ \text{So, }0&=100e^{-10^4t_1} \\ t_1&=0.46msec \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 The line currents of a three-phase four wire system are square waves with amplitude of 100 A. These three currents are phase shifted by 120[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] with respect to each other. The rms value of neutral current is
solution: [latex]I_N=I_a+I_b+I_c [/latex] [latex](I_N)_{rms}=100A[/latex]

question: Question 35 The current I flowing in the circuit shown below in amperes (round off to one decimal place) is ____
solution: Applying nodal at node x, [latex]-I-2+\frac{V_x-5I}{3}=0 [/latex] [latex]-3I-6+V_x-5I=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 8I=V_x-6\;\;...(i) [/latex] As,  [latex]I=\frac{20-V_x}{2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; V_x=20-2I\;\;...(ii)[/latex] Substituting (ii) in (i), [latex]8I=20-2I-6 [/latex] [latex]10I=14 [/latex] [latex]I=1.4A[/latex]

question:
Question 36 The voltage v(t) across the terminals a and b as shown in the figure, is a sinusoidal voltage
having a frequency [latex]\omega[/latex]=100 radian/s. When the inductor current i(t) is in phase with the
voltage v(t), the magnitude of the impedance Z (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) seen between the terminals a and b
is ________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: At resonance imaginary part of [latex]Z_{eq}=0 [/latex] Real of [latex] Z_{eq}=\frac{R_1 X_c^2}{R_1^2+X-c^2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100 \times 100 \times 100}{100^2+100^2}=50\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 37 The voltage across the circuit in the figure, and the current through it, are given by the
following expressions: [latex]v(t) = 5 - 10 cos(\omega t + 60^{\circ}) V [/latex] [latex]i(t) = 5 + X cos(\omega t) A[/latex] where [latex]\omega =100 \pi[/latex] radian/s. If the average power delivered to the circuit is zero, then the
value of X (in Ampere) is _____ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given that, [latex]v(t)=5-10 \cos (\omega t+60^{\circ}) [/latex] [latex]i(t)=5+C \cos (\omega t-0^{\circ}) [/latex] [latex]P_{req}=0 [/latex] [latex]0=5 \times 5 +\frac{1}{2}[(-10)(X)\cos(60^{\circ})] [/latex] [latex]-25=\frac{1}{2}[(-10)(X)\cos(60^{\circ})] [/latex] [latex]X=10[/latex]

question: Question 38 The equivalent impedance [latex]Z_{eq}[/latex] for the infinite ladder circuit shown in the figure is

Question 39 A DC voltage source is connected to a series L-C circuit by turning on the switch S at time t=0 as shown in the figure. Assume i(0)=0, v(0)=0. Which one of the following
circular loci represents the plot of i(t) versus v(t) ?
solution: [latex]I(s)=\frac{\frac{5}{s}}{s+\frac{1}{s}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{5}{s^2+1} [/latex] [latex]i(t)=5 \sin t [/latex] [latex]v(t)=\frac{1}{C}\int_{0}^{t}i \; dt [/latex] [latex]v(t)=\int_{0}^{t}5 \sin t \; dt [/latex] [latex]v(t)=5[-\cos t]_0^t [/latex] [latex]v(t)=5[-\cos t+1] [/latex] [latex]v(t)=5-5 \cos t[/latex] [latex]\begin{matrix} t & i(t) & v(t)\\ 0 & 0 & 0\\ \frac{T}{4} & 5 & 5\\ \frac{T}{2}& 0 & 10\\ \frac{3T}{4} &-5 & 5\\ T& 0 & 0 \end{matrix}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 In the two-port network shown, the [latex]h_{11}[/latex] parameter 
(where, [latex]h_{11}=\frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}[/latex], when [latex]V_{2}[/latex] =0) in ohms
is _____________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: By KCL, [latex]\frac{V_a-1}{1}+\frac{V_a}{1}+\frac{V_a+2I_1}{1}=0 [/latex] [latex]3V_a+2I_1=1\;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex] I_1=\frac{1-V_a}{1}\;\;...(ii) [/latex] Substitute equation (ii) in equation (i) [/latex] [latex]V_a=-1 [/latex] [latex]I_1=\frac{1-V_a}{1}=\frac{1-(-1)}{1}=2 [/latex] [latex]h_{11}=\frac{V_1}{I_1}=\frac{1}{2}=0.5\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 41 In the figure, the voltages are [latex]v_{1}(t)=100cos(\omega t)[/latex], [latex]v_{2} (t) = 100cos(\omega t + \pi /18)[/latex] and [latex]v_{3}(t) = 100cos(\omega t + \pi /36)[/latex]. The circuit is in sinusoidal steady state, and [latex]R \lt \lt \omega L[/latex]. [latex]P_{1}[/latex],[latex]P_{2}[/latex] and [latex]P_{3}[/latex] are the average power outputs. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: [latex]V_2:\frac{\pi}{18}=\frac{180^{\circ}}{18}=10^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]V_3:\frac{\pi}{36}=\frac{180^{\circ}}{36}=5^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]V_2[/latex] leads [latex]V_1 [/latex] and [latex]V_3[/latex], So, [latex]V_2[/latex]is a source, [latex]V_1[/latex] and [latex]V_3[/latex] are absorbing. Hence, [latex]P_2 \gt 0[/latex] and [latex]P_1,P_3 \lt 0[/latex]

the graph is

Question 43 In the circuit shown below, the value of capacitor C required for maximum power to be
transferred to the load is
solution: The frequency at which the load is resistive and it is equal to [latex]0.5\Omega[/latex] i.e. The load is resistive means, the imaginary part of load is equal to zero and real part is equal to [latex]0.5\Omega[/latex]. [latex]Z_{load}=\frac{1 \times \frac{1}{Cs}}{1 + \frac{1}{Cs}}+Ls[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{1+Cs}+Ls[/latex] [latex]\;\; =\frac{(1-Cs)}{1-C^2s^2}+Ls [/latex] Put,  [latex] s=j\omega[/latex]; [latex] Z_{load}=\frac{1-j\omega C}{1+C^2\omega ^2}+j\omega L [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{1}{1+C^2\omega ^2}+j\omega \left ( L-\frac{C}{(1+C^2\omega ^2)} \right ) [/latex] Real part of the [latex]Z_{load}=\frac{1}{1+C^2\omega ^2}=0.5 [/latex] Putting, [latex]\omega =100 r/s[/latex] we get, [latex]C=10mF[/latex]

question: Question 44 For the network given in figure below, the Thevenin's voltage [latex]V_{ab}[/latex] is
solution: Consider the following circuit, After rearrangement, we get, From circuit using KCL, [latex]\frac{V_{ab}+30}{15}+\frac{V_{ab}-8}{5}=0 [/latex] [latex]V_{ab}+30+3V_{ab}-24=0 [/latex] [latex]V_{ab}=-1.5V[/latex]

question:
Question 45 The initial charge in the 1 F capacitor present in the circuit shown is zero. The energy in joules
transferred from the DC source until steady state condition is reached equals ______. (Give the
answer up to one decimal place.)
solution: Consider the following circuit diagram, After minimizing circuit elements we can have the following circuit, Here, [latex]\tau =RC=5 sec.[/latex] Now current, [latex] i(t)=\frac{V}{R}e^{\frac{t}{\tau }}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{10}{5}e^{-t/5}=2e^{-0.2t} [/latex] Energy supplied by the source, [latex] E=\int_{0}^{\infty }10 \times 2e^{-0.2t}dt[/latex] [latex] \;\;=100J[/latex]

question: Question 46 For the given 2-port network, the value of transfer impedance [latex]Z_{21}[/latex] in ohms is_______

question: Question 48 In the circuit shown below, the maximum power transferred to the resistor R is _______ W.
solution: To get [latex]R_{th}[/latex] and [latex]V_{th}[/latex], consider the following steps. Case-1: For [latex]R_{th}[/latex] For [latex]V_{th}[/latex] Applying KCL at node, [latex]\frac{V_{th}-5}{5}+\frac{V_{th}+16}{5}=0 [/latex] [latex]2V_{th}=-11 [/latex] [latex]V_{th}=-5.5 V [/latex] Maximum power transferred, [latex]P_{max}=\frac{V_{th}^2}{4R_{th}}= \frac{5.5^2}{4 \times 2.5}=3.025W[/latex]

question:
Question 49 Two passive two-port networks are connected in cascade as shown in figure. A voltage source is
connected at port 1. Given [latex]V_{1}=A_{1}V_{2}+B_{1}I_{2}[/latex] [latex] I_{1}=C_{1}V_{2}+D_{1}I_{2}[/latex] [latex] V_{2}=A_{2}V_{3}+B_{2}I_{3}[/latex] [latex] I_{2}=C_{2}V_{3}+D_{2}I_{3} [/latex] [latex]A_{1},B_{1},C_{1},D_{1},A_{2},B_{2},C_{2} \; and \; D_{2}[/latex] are the generalized circuit constants. If the Thevenin equivalent circuit at port 3 consists of a voltage source [latex]V_T[/latex] and impedance [latex]Z_T[/latex] connected in series, then
solution: For two port network, we can write, [latex]\begin{bmatrix} A &B \\ C & D \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} A_1 & B_1\\ C_1 & D_1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} A_2 & B_2\\ C_2 & D_2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex] A=A_1A_2+B_1C_2\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]B=A_1B_2+B_1D_2\;\;...(ii) [/latex] [latex]V_1=AV_2-BI_2\;\;...(iii) [/latex] To get, [latex]V_T(I_2=0)[/latex]; from equation (iii) [latex]V_2=V_T=\frac{V_1}{A}=\frac{V_1}{A_1A_2+B_1C_2} [/latex] To get [latex]Z_T(V_1=0)[/latex]; from equation (iii) [latex]V_1=AV_2-BI_2 [/latex] [latex]0=AV_2-BI_2[/latex] [latex] Z_T=\frac{V_2}{I_2}=\frac{B}{A}=\frac{A_1B_2+B_1D_2}{A_1A_2+B_1C_2}[/latex]

question: Question 50 The power supplied by the 25 V source in the figure shown below is ________W.

question: Question 51 The equivalent resistance between the terminals A and B is ______ [latex]\Omega[/latex].

question: Question 52 In the circuit shown below, the initial capacitor voltage is 4 V. Switch [latex]S_1[/latex] is closed at t=0. The charge (in [latex]\mu[/latex]C) lost by the capacitor from t=25[latex]\mu s[/latex] to t=100[latex]\mu s[/latex] is ____________.
solution: [latex]i(t)=\frac{4}{5}e^{-t/\tau }[/latex] [latex] \tau =RC [/latex] [latex]\;\;=20 \times 10^{-6}sec [/latex] Change lost by capacitor from [latex]t=25\mu s[/latex] to [latex]100\mu s[/latex] is [latex]\int_{25 \mu s}^{100\mu s}i(t)dt=6.99 \times 10^{-6}C[/latex]

question: Question 53 In the balanced 3-phase, 50 Hz, circuit shown below, the value of inductance (L) is 10 mH. The value of the capacitance (C) for which all the line currents are zero, in millifarads, is ___________.
solution: Usingstar to delta conversion, Line current will be zero when the parallel pair of induction capacitor is resonant at f=50Hz So, [latex]50 \times 2\pi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC/3}} [/latex] [latex]100 \pi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC/3}} [/latex] Since, L=10mH C will be 3.03 mF.

question: Question 54 The z-parameters of the two port network shown in the figure are [latex]z_{11}=40\Omega ,z_{12}=60\Omega ,z_{21}=80\Omega [/latex]  and  [latex] z_{22}=100 \Omega[/latex]. The average power delivered to [latex]R_{L}=20\Omega[/latex], in watts, is _______.
solution: Given, [latex]Z_{11}=40\Omega ,Z_{12}=60\Omega [/latex] [latex]Z_{21}=80\Omega ,Z_{22}=100\Omega [/latex] From the figure, [latex]V_2=-20I_2\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]V_1=40I_1+60I_2\;\;...(ii)[/latex] [latex] V_2=80I_1+100I_2\;\;...(iii)[/latex] From equation (i) and (iii), we get [latex]-20I_2=80I_1+100I_2 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_2=-\frac{2}{3}I_1\;\;...(iv)[/latex] Using equation (ii) and (iv), we get [latex]V_1=40I_1+60I_2[/latex] [latex] \;\;=40I_1+60\left ( \frac{-2}{3} I_1\right ) [/latex] [latex]V_1=0[/latex] From the figure, [latex]20=10I_1+V_1 [/latex] Since,  [latex] V_1=0 [/latex] So, [latex]I_1=2A [/latex] [latex] I_2=\frac{-4}{3}A [/latex] Power dissipated in [latex]P_{R_L}=I_2^2R_L=\left ( \frac{4}{3} \right )^2 \times 20 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{16}{9} \times 20=35.55W[/latex]

question: Question 55 The driving point input impedance seen from the source [latex]V_s[/latex] of the circuit shown below, in [latex]\Omega[/latex], is ______.
solution: To find impedance seen by [latex]V_s [/latex] [latex]Z_s=\frac{V_s}{I_s} [/latex] [latex]V_1=2I_s[/latex] Applying KCL at node A, [latex]I_s=4V_1=\frac{V_A}{3}+\frac{V_A}{6}[/latex] [latex] V_A=V_s-V_1 [/latex] and  [latex]V_1=2I_s [/latex] So, [latex]I_s+8I_s=\frac{V_s-2I_s}{3}+\frac{V_s-2I_s}{6} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 54I_s=2V_s-4I_s+V_s-2I_s [/latex] [latex]3V_s=60I_s [/latex] [latex]\frac{V_s}{I_s}=20\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 56 The graph associated with an electrical network has 7 branches and 5 nodes. The number of independent KCL equations and the number of independent KVL equations, respectively, are
solution: Number of KCL equations = n-1=5-1=4 Number of KVL equations =b-(n-1) = 7-(5-1)=3

question: Question 57 In the circuit shown below, the voltage and current sources are ideal. The voltage ([latex]V_{out}[/latex]) across the current source, in volts, is
solution: So, [latex]V_{out}=(5 \times 2 )+10=20V[/latex]

question: Question 58 The voltage (V) and current (A) across a load are as follows. [latex]v(t) = 100 sin(\omega t)[/latex], [latex]i(t) = 10 sin(\omega t - 60^{\circ}) + 2 sin(3\omega t) + 5 sin(5\omega t)[/latex]. The average power consumed by the load, in W, is___________.
solution: The average power consumed by the load = [latex]P=V_1I_1 \cos \phi [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100}{\sqrt{2}}\frac{10}{\sqrt{2}} \cos 60^{\circ}=250W[/latex]

question: Question 60 The following figure shows the connection of an ideal transformer with primary to secondary turns ratio of 1:100. The applied primary voltage is 100 V (rms), 50 Hz, AC. The rms value of the current I, in ampere, is __________.
solution: The above circuit can be drown by transferring secondary circuit to primary side. [latex]I=\frac{100V}{(8+10j-4j)\Omega }[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100V}{(8+6j)\Omega }[/latex] So the rms value of I will be 10 A.

question: Question 61 In the circuit shown below, the node voltage In the circuit shown below, the node voltage [latex]V_{A}[/latex] is ___________ V.
solution: Applying KCL at node A, we get [latex]\frac{V_A}{5}+\frac{V_A-10}{10}+\frac{V_A+10I_1}{5}=5 [/latex] So, [latex]2V_A+V_A-10+2V_A+20I_1=5 [/latex] [latex]5V_A+20I_1=60 [/latex] Since,  [latex]I_1=\frac{V_A-10}{10}[/latex] So, [latex] 5V_A+2V_A-20=60 [/latex] [latex]7V_A=80 [/latex] [latex]V_A=11.42 volt[/latex]

question: Question 62 The circuit below is excited by a sinusoidal source. The value of R, in [latex]\Omega[/latex], for which the admittance of the circuit becomes a pure conductance at all frequencies is _____________.
solution: The resonant frequency for the circuit is [latex]\omega _0=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}\sqrt{\frac{R_L^2-L/C}{R_C^2-L/C}}[/latex] Since, [latex]  (R_L=R_C=R) [/latex] So the circuit will have zero real part of admittance when, [latex]R=\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}=\sqrt{\frac{0.02}{100\mu F}}=14.14\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 63 In the circuit shown below, the supply voltage is [latex]10sin(1000t)[/latex] volts. The peak value of the steady state current through the 1[latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor, in amperes, is ______.
solution: If we observe the parallel LC combination, we get that at [latex]\omega[/latex]=1000 rad/sec the parallel LC is at resonance, thus it is open circuited. The circuit given in question can be redrawn as So, [latex]I=\frac{10 \sin 1000t}{10}=\sin 100t[/latex] So, peak value is 1 Amp.

question: Question 64 In the circuit shown, switch [latex]S_2[/latex] has been closed for a long time. At time t=0  switch [latex]S_1[/latex] is closed. At  [latex]t = 0^{+}[/latex], the rate of change of current through the inductor, in amperes per second, is _____.
solution: KCL at node A, [latex]\frac{V_A-3}{1}+\frac{3}{2}+\frac{V_A-3}{2}=0 [/latex] [latex]2(V_A-3)+3+(V_A-3)=0 [/latex] [latex]3V_A=6 [/latex] [latex]V_A=2 [/latex] [latex]V_A=L\frac{di(0^+)}{dt}=2[/latex] [latex] \frac{di(0^+)}{dt}=\frac{2}{L}=\frac{2}{1}=2A/sec[/latex]

question: Question 65 In the given circuit, the current supplied by the battery, in ampere, is _______.
solution: Applying KCL at node A, [latex]-I_1+I_2+I_2=0 [/latex] [latex]2I_2=I_1\;\;...(i)[/latex] and applying KVL in loop ABCD, [latex]1-I_1-I_2-I_2=0 [/latex] [latex]I_1+2I_2=1\;\;...(ii) [/latex] From equation (i) and (ii), [latex] \Rightarrow \; 2I_2+2I_2=1 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 4I_2=1 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_2=\frac{1}{4}A [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_1=2 \times \frac{1}{4}=\frac{1}{2}A[/latex]

question: Question 66 In the portion of a circuit shown, if the heat generated in 5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance is 10 calories per second, then heat generated by the 4 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance, in calories per second, is _______.
solution: [latex](2I)^2 \times 5 =10 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I^2=\frac{10}{5 \times 5}=0.5 [/latex] So, [latex] I^2 \times 4 =2 cal/sec.[/latex]

question: Question 67 [latex]R_{A} \; and \; R_{B}[/latex] are the input resistances of circuits as shown below. The circuits extend infinitely in the direction shown. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: If the equavalent resistance of first figure is [latex]R_A[/latex] then from the second figure, we can see that [latex]R_B=R_A||1\Omega[/latex]. [latex]R_B=\frac{R_A}{R_A+1}[/latex]

question: Question 68 Two identical coils each having inductance L are placed together on the same core. If an overall inductance of [latex]\alpha[/latex]L is obtained by interconnecting these two coils, the minimum value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] is ____.
solution: CASE-I: [latex]L_{eff}=L_+L_2=2L,[/latex],  a=2 CASE-II: [latex] l_{eff}=\frac{L_1L_2}{L_1+L_2}=\frac{L^2}{2L}=\frac{L}{2}[/latex], a=0.5 CASE-III If both are diffferentially coupled then [latex]L_{eff}=0[/latex] Minimum value =0

question: Question 69 A symmetrical square wave of 50% duty cycle has amplitude of [latex]\pm[/latex]15 V and time period of 0.4[latex]\pi[/latex] ms. This square wave is applied across a series RLC circuit with R=5 [latex]\Omega[/latex], L=10 mH, and C=4 [latex]\mu[/latex]F. The amplitude of the 5000 rad/s component of the capacitor voltage (in Volt) is ______.

Question 70 In the given network [latex]V_{1}=100\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex]V,  [latex]V_{2}=-120\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] V, [latex]V_{3}=+120\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] V. The phasor current i (in Ampere) is
solution: [latex]'i'[/latex] is taken as input, Apply KCL at node Node voltage is [latex]100\angle 120^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]i=\frac{100\angle 120^{\circ}-100\angle 0^{\circ}}{-j1} [/latex]  [latex]+\frac{100\angle 120^{\circ}-100\angle -120^{\circ}}{j1} [/latex] [latex]i=173.2\angle -60^{\circ}A[/latex]

question: Question 71 Find the transformer ratios a and b such that the impedance ([latex]Z_{in}[/latex]) is resistive and equals 2.5[latex]\Omega[/latex] when the network is excited with a sine wave voltage of angular frequency of 5000 rad/s.
solution: [latex](R_{eq})_B=\frac{2.5}{a^2} [/latex] [latex](2eq)_B=\left [ \frac{2.5}{a^2}+j\omega (1 \times 10^{-3})\right ] [/latex] [latex](2eq)_A={\left [ \frac{2.5}{a^2}+j\omega (1 \times 10^{-3})\right ]}/b^2 [/latex] [latex]Z_{in}=\frac{2.5}{a^2b^2}+\frac{ j\omega 10^{-3}}{b^2}+\frac{1}{j\omega (10 \times 10^{-5})} [/latex] [latex]Z_{in}=\frac{2.5}{a^2b^2}+j\left [ \frac{5 \times 10^3 \times 10^{-3}}{b^2} -\frac{1}{5 \times 10^3 \times 10 \times10^{-6}}\right ] \;...(i) [/latex] From problem, [latex]Z_{in}=2.5 \;\;...(ii) [/latex] From equation (i) and (ii), [latex]a^2b^2=1 [/latex] [latex]\frac{5}{b^2}-\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{-2}}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; b=0.5 \text{ and } a=2[/latex]

question: Question 72 The current i (in Ampere) in the  2[latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor of the given network is ______.
solution: Redrawing the circuit, Bridge is balance, so current flowing through [latex]2\Omega[/latex] resistor is 0A.

question: Question 73 A series RL circuit is excited at t = 0 by closing a switch as shown in the figure. Assuming zero initial conditions, the value of [latex]\frac{d^{2}i}{dt^{2}}\;  at \; t=0^{+}[/latex] is
solution: Initially [latex](t=0^-)[/latex] the inductor would be uncharged. So, [latex]I(0^+)=0[/latex] The KVL in th loop will be [latex]V=RI+L\frac{dI}{dt}[/latex] At [latex]t=0^+ [/latex] [latex]V=RI(0^+)+L\frac{dI}{dt}(0^+) [/latex] Since, [latex] I(0^+)=0 [/latex] So, [latex]\frac{dI}{dt}(0^+)=\frac{V}{L} [/latex] Now, lets differentiate the above equation So,[latex] \frac{dV}{dt}=R\frac{dI}{dt}+L\frac{d^2I}{dt^2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;0=R\frac{dI}{dt}+L\frac{d^2I}{dt^2} [/latex] At [latex]t=0^+[/latex] [latex] 0=R\frac{dI}{dt}(0^+)+L\frac{d^2I}{dt^2}(0^+) [/latex] So, [latex] \frac{d^2I}{dt^2}(0^+)=-\frac{R}{L^2}\cdot V[/latex]

question: Question 74 In the given circuit, the parameter k is positive, and the power dissipated in the 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor is 12.5W. The value of k is _________.
solution: [latex]\Rightarrow \; \frac{V_0^2}{2}=12.5 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; V_0^2=12.5 \times 2 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; V_0=5 [/latex] KCL at A, [latex]\Rightarrow \; -2.5-k(5)+5=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; k=\frac{2.5}{5}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 75 In a linear two-port network, when 10 V is applied to Port 1, a current of 4 A flows through Port 2 when it is short-circuited. When 5 V is applied to Port 1, a current of 1.25 A flows through a 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance connected across Port 2. When 3 V is applied to Port 1, the current (in Ampere) through a 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance connected across Port 2 is _______.
solution: [latex]V_1=10V, I_2=4 A, V_2=0\;\;Cond...(i)[/latex] [latex]V_1=5V, I_2=1.25 A,[/latex]  [latex] V_2=1.25 \times 1=1.25V\;\;Cond...(ii)[/latex] [latex] V_1=3V, I_2=? , R=2\Omega \;\;Cond...(iii)[/latex] as we know from ABCD parameter, [latex]V_1=AV_2-BI_2 [/latex] [latex]I_1=CV_2-DI_2 [/latex] From condition (i), [latex]10=A(0)-B(4) [/latex] [latex]B=-\frac{10}{4} [/latex] From condition (ii), [latex] 5=A(1.25)-\left ( -\frac{10}{4} \right ) \times 1.25 [/latex] [latex]A=\frac{\left ( 5-\frac{12.5}{4} \right )}{1.25}=1.5 [/latex] From condition (iii), [latex] 3=1.5(2I)-\left ( -\frac{10}{4} \right )\times I [/latex] [latex]3=3I+2.5I [/latex] [latex]I=0.545 A[/latex]

question: Question 76 The circuit s hown in the figure has two sources connected in series. The instantaneous voltage of the AC source (in Volt) is given by [latex]v(t)=12\sin t[/latex]. If the circuit is in steady state, then the rms value of the current (in Ampere) flowing in the circuit is ______ .
solution: [latex]i(t)=\frac{8}{1}+\frac{12 \sin t}{\sqrt{1+1}}=8+6\sqrt{2} \sin t [/latex] [latex]i_{rms}(t)=\sqrt{8^2+\frac{1}{2}(6\sqrt{2} )^2}=10A[/latex]

question: Question 77 An inductor is connected in parallel with a capacitor as shown in the figure. As the frequency of current i is increased, the impedance (Z) of the network varies as
solution: [latex]Z=j\omega L||\frac{1}{j\omega C}[/latex] [latex] \;\;=\frac{L/C}{j\omega L+\frac{1}{j\omega C}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{(L/C)j\omega C}{-\omega ^2 LC+1} [/latex] [latex]Z=\frac{j\omega L}{1-\omega^2 LC} [/latex] [latex]|Z|=\frac{\omega L}{1-\omega^2 LC} [/latex] For,  [latex] 1\gt \omega^2 LC; [/latex] [latex]Z=+ve[/latex] For, [latex]1 \lt \omega^2 LC;[/latex] [latex] Z=-ve[/latex]

question: Question 78 For the given circuit, the Thevenin equivalent is to be determined. The Thevenin voltage, [latex]V_{Th}[/latex] (in Volt), seen from terminal AB is __________.
solution: [latex]2-1(i_1+i)-i=0 [/latex] [latex]2-i_1-2i=0 [/latex] [latex]2i + i_1=2\;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex] \frac{V-2}{1}+\frac{V}{1}+\frac{V-(-20i)}{2}=0 [/latex] [latex]2(V-2)+2V+V+20i=0 [/latex] [latex]5V+20i=4 [/latex] where,  [latex] \frac{V}{1}=i [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 25i=4 [/latex] [latex]i=\frac{4}{25}A [/latex] [latex]i_1=2-2 \times \frac{4}{25} =1.68A [/latex] [latex]V_{AB}=1.68 \times 2=3.36 V[/latex]

question: Question 79 The voltages developed across the 3 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistors shown in the figure are 6 V and 2V respectively, with the polarity as marked. What is the power (in Watt) delivered by the 5V voltage source?
solution: Power =5x1=5 Watt

question:
Question 80 A series RLC circuit is observed at two frequencies. At  [latex]\omega _1[/latex]=1 krad/s, we note
that source voltage [latex]V_{1}=100\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] V results in a current [latex]I_{1}=0.03 \angle 31 ^{\circ}A[/latex]. At  [latex]\omega _2[/latex]=2 krad/s, the source voltage [latex]V_{2}=100\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex]  V results in a current [latex]I_{2}=2 \angle 0^{\circ}[/latex]. The closest values for R, L, C out of the following options are
solution: Given [latex]\omega _1=1 k [/latex] rad/s, [latex]V_1=100\angle 0^{\circ}V,  [/latex] [latex]I_1=0.03\angle 31^{\circ}A [/latex] At,   [latex]\omega _2=2 k[/latex]  rad/s, [latex]V_2=100\angle 0^{\circ}V, [/latex] [latex]I_2=2\angle 0^{\circ}A [/latex] At [latex]\omega _2=2 k[/latex] rad/s, voltage and current are in phase. Thus, it is a case of series resonance, [latex]X_{L_{\omega 2}}=X_{C_{\omega 2}} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;Z=R=\frac{V_2}{I_2}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100\angle 0^{\circ}}{2\angle 0^{\circ}}=50\Omega [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Resistance of circuit, [latex]R=50\Omega [/latex] Now at [latex]\omega _1=1 k[/latex] rad/s, [latex] Z=\frac{V_1}{I_1}=\frac{100\angle 0^{\circ}}{0.03\angle 31^{\circ}}[/latex] [latex]\;\; =\frac{100}{0.03}\angle 31^{\circ}\Omega\;\;...(i) [/latex] Also,  [latex] Z=|Z|\angle \tan^{-1}\left [ \frac{X_L-X_C}{R} \right ] \;\;...(ii)[/latex] Comparing equation (i) and (ii), we have: [latex] -31^{\circ}=\tan ^{-1}\left [ \frac{X_L-X_C}{R} \right ][/latex] [latex] \tan(-31^{\circ})=\frac{X_L-X_C}{R} [/latex] [latex]X_L-X_C=R \tan(-31^{\circ}) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=50X-0.6=-30 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; X_{L_{\omega 1}}-X_{C_{\omega 2}}=-30\;\;...(iii) [/latex] [latex]X_{L_{\omega 2}}=X_{C_{\omega 2}} [/latex] or [latex] \omega _2 L=\frac{1}{\omega _2C} [/latex] [latex]L=\frac{1}{\omega _2^2C}\;\;...(iv) [/latex] From equation (iii), [latex] \omega _1L-\frac{1}{\omega _1C}=-30 [/latex] [latex]\omega _1\left ( \frac{1}{\omega _2^2C}\right )-\frac{1}{\omega _1C}=-30[/latex] [latex] \frac{\omega _1}{\omega _2^2C}-\frac{1}{\omega _1C}=-30 [/latex] [latex]\frac{1 \times 10^3}{4 \times 10^6 C}-\frac{1}{10^3C}=-30 [/latex] [latex]\frac{10^{-3}}{4C}-\frac{10^{-3}}{C}=-30 [/latex] [latex]\frac{-3}{4C} \times 10^{-3}=-30 [/latex] [latex]C=\frac{3 \times 10^{-3}}{4 \times 30} [/latex] Substituting the value of C in equation (iv), we get, [latex]L=\frac{1}{\omega _2^2C}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{(2 \times 10^3)^2 \times 25 \times 10^{-6}}[/latex] [latex]\;\; =\frac{1}{100}=10mH[/latex] Therefore, values are: [latex]R=50\Omega , [/latex] [latex]L=10mH, [/latex] [latex]C=25\mu F[/latex]

question: Question 81 The power delivered by the current source, in the figure, is ____.
solution: Applying nodal analysis at node P, we have [latex]\frac{V_I-V_1}{1}+\frac{V_I-V_2}{1}-2=0 [/latex] [latex]2V_I-(V_1+V_2)=2 [/latex] [latex]V_I=\left [ \frac{2+(V_1+V_2)}{2} \right ]\;\;...(i) [/latex] Also,  [latex]V_1-V_2=1[/latex] volt and [latex]V_1=1[/latex] volt [latex]\therefore \;\; V_2=V_1-1=1-1=0 volt [/latex] Putting values of  [latex]V_1[/latex] and [latex]V_2[/latex] in equation (i), we get: [latex] V_I=\left [ \frac{2+(1+0)}{2} \right ]=\frac{3}{2}volt [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Power delivered by the current source [latex] =V_I\cdot I=\frac{3}{2} \times 2 \;\;[\because \; I=2A (given)][/latex] [latex]=3 Watts[/latex]

question: Question 82 The Norton's equivalent source in amperes as seen into terminals X and Y is ____.
solution: Using source transformation theoram, or we can simplify the network, Now, from the circuit, we get, [latex]I_N=\frac{5}{5}=1A[/latex]

question: Question 83 A non-ideal voltage source [latex]V_{s}[/latex] has an internal impedance of [latex]Z_{s}[/latex]. If a purely resistive load is to be chosen that maximizes the power transferred to the load, its value must be
solution: Thesituation of problem is shown in figure: For the transfer of maximum power from source to load, [latex]R_L=\sqrt{R_s^2+X^2}=|Z|[/latex]

question: Question 84 The driving point impedance Z(s) for the circuit shown below is
solution: Driving point impedance, Z(s) is , [latex]Z(s)=s+\left ( \frac{\left ( s+\frac{1}{s} \right )\times \frac{1}{s}}{s+\frac{1}{s}+\frac{1}{s}} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=s+\left ( \frac{s^2+1}{s^2} \right )\times \frac{s}{s^2+2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=s+\frac{s^2+1}{s(s^2+2)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{s^2(s^2+2)+^2+1}{s^3+2s} [/latex] [latex]Z(s)=\frac{s^4+3s^2+1}{s^3+2s}[/latex]

question: Question 85 The line A to neutral voltage is [latex]10 \angle 15^{\circ}[/latex]V for a balanced three phase star connected load with phase sequence ABC . The voltage of line B with respect to line C is given by
solution: Given, [latex]V_{AN}=10\angle 15^{\circ}volt[/latex] As the system is balanced and phase sequence is ABC, therefore, [latex]V_{AN}=10\angle 15^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]V_{BN}=10\angle 135^{\circ}V[/latex] and  [latex]V_{CN}=10\angle 255^{\circ}V [/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex]  voltage of line w.r.t. line C is [latex] V_{BC}=V_{BN}-V_{CN}[/latex] [latex] V_{BC}=10\angle 255^{\circ}-10\angle 135^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]V_{BC}=10\sqrt{3}\angle -75^{\circ} Volt[/latex]

question: Question 86 The total power dissipated in the circuit, shown in the figure, is 1 kW. The voltmeter, across the load, reads 200 V. The value of [latex]X_L[/latex] is _____.
solution: Given, total power dissipated in the circuit = 1kW =1000 Watt [latex]\therefore \;\; 2^2 \times 1 +10^2 \times R=1000 [/latex] [latex]R=\frac{998}{100}=9.98\Omega [/latex] Also, voltage drop across R, [latex]V_R=IR[/latex] [latex]=10 \times 9.98=99.8 volt [/latex] Voltage drop across load, [latex]V=200 volt =\sqrt{V_R^2+V_{X_L}^2} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] voltage drop across inductor, [latex] V_{X_L}=\sqrt{V^2-V_R^2}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\sqrt{(200)^2-(99.8)^2}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=173.32 volt [/latex] Now, [latex] V_{X_L}=IX_L[/latex] [latex] X_L=\frac{V_{X_L}}{I} [/latex] [latex]X_L=\frac{173.32}{10}=17.332\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 87 The voltage across the capacitor, as shown in the figure, is expressed as [latex]v_{c}(t)=A_{1}sin(\omega _{1}t-\theta _{1})+A_{2}sin(\omega _{2}t-\theta _{2})[/latex] The values of [latex]A_1 \; and \; A_2[/latex]  respectively, are
solution: Let us apply superposition theorem, Consider the voltage source 20sint alone Then, 10sin5t  remain open circuited. Let, [latex]V_{c1}(t)[/latex] be the voltage across capacitor [latex]V_{c1}(t)=\left ( \frac{-j0.1}{1-j0.1} \right ) \times 20 \sin 10t [/latex] [latex]\;\;=(1.99\angle -84.28^{\circ}) \sin 10t [/latex] [latex]V_{c1}(t)=2 \sin (10t-84.28^{\circ}) [/latex] Considering the current source [latex]10 \sin 5t[/latex] alone. Then, [latex] 20 \sin 10t[/latex] voltage source remain short circuited Let voltage across capacitor [latex]=V_{c2}(t)[/latex] [latex]\frac{V_{c1}}{1}+\frac{V_{c2}}{(-j0.2)}-10 \sin 5t=0 [/latex] [latex]V_{c2}(t)=\frac{10 \sin 5t}{(1+j5)} [/latex] [latex]V_{c2}(t)=1.97 \sin(5t-78.69^{\circ})\;\;...(i) [/latex] Using superposition theoram, voltage across capacitor is [latex]V_c(t)=V_{c1}(t)+V_{c1}(t) [/latex] [latex]V_c(t)=2 \sin (10t-84.28^{\circ})[/latex] [latex]+1.97 \sin (5t-78.69^{\circ})\;\;...(ii) [/latex] Given,  [latex] V_c(t)=A_1 \sin (\omega_1 t-\theta _1)[/latex]  [latex]+A_2 \sin (\omega _2 t -\theta _2)\;\;...(iv)[/latex] Comparing equation (iii) and (iv), we have A=2 and B=1.97 [latex]\approx [/latex]1.98

question:
Question 88 Assuming an ideal transformer, the Thevenin's equivalent voltage and impedance
as seen from the terminals x and y for the circuit in figure are
solution: Thevenin's equivalent voltage=voltage referred to secondary. We have: [latex]\frac{\sin \omega t}{V_{Th}}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] [latex]V_{Th}=2 \sin (\omega t)[/latex] Also, Thevenin's impedance seen from the x and y terminals=voltage referred to secondary side [latex]\therefore \;\;Z_{Th}=R_{Th}=2^2\times 1=4\Omega [/latex] So,  [latex]V_{Th}= 2 \sin (\omega t) [/latex] and  [latex] Z_{Th}=R_{Th}=4\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 89 The switch SW shown in the circuit is kept at position '1' for a long duration. At t=0+, the switch is moved to position '2'. Assuming [latex]|V_{o2} | \gt |V_{o1}|[/latex], the voltage [latex]v_{c}(t)[/latex] across the capacitor is

Question 90 Two identical coupled inductors are connected in series. The measured inductances
for the two possible series connections are 380 [latex]\mu[/latex]H and 240 [latex]\mu[/latex]H. Their mutual inductance in [latex]\mu[/latex]H is _____.
solution: The two possible series connection are shown below: Let the mutual inductance be M (i) Additive connection, (ii) Substractive connection, [latex]L_{eqv}=L_1+L_2-2M=240\mu H[/latex] Thus,  [latex]  L_1+L_2+2M=380 \mu H\;\;...(i) [/latex] and [latex]L_1+L_2-2M=240 \mu H\;\;...(ii) [/latex] Solving equations (i) and (ii), we get: [latex] 4M=140\mu H [/latex] [latex]M=35\mu H [/latex] Therefore, mutual inductance [latex]M=35\mu H[/latex]

question:
Question 91 In the figure, the value of resistor R is (25 + I/2) ohms, where I is the current in
amperes. The current I is _____.
solution: Given, [latex]R=\left ( 25+\frac{I}{2} \right )\Omega [/latex] [latex]I=(2R-50) [/latex] Applying KVL in given loop, we have [latex] 300=IR[/latex] [latex] 300=(2R-50)\times R [/latex] we get, [latex]R=30\Omega \; or \; -5\Omega[/latex] Since, resistance can't be negative. therefore, [latex]R=30\Omega [/latex] Hence,  [latex] I=(2R-50) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=(2 \times 30-50)=10A [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; Current, I=10A[/latex]

question: Question 92 An incandescent lamp is marked 40 W, 240 V. If resistance at room temperature (26[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C) is 120 [latex]\Omega[/latex], and temperature coefficient of resistance is [latex]4.5\times 10^{-3}/^{\circ}[/latex]C, then its 'ON' state filament temperature in [latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is approximately_____.
solution: Let the resistance of incandescent lamp [latex]=R_T=\frac{V^2}{P}=\frac{(240)^2}{40}=1440\Omega[/latex] Given,  [latex]  R_0=120\Omega ,[/latex] [latex]\alpha =4.5 \times 10^{-3}/^{\circ}C [/latex] Let, [latex]R_T[/latex] be the resistance of the filament in ON state at temperature T. Then, [latex] R_T=R_0[1+\alpha \Delta T] [/latex] [latex][1+\alpha \Delta T]=\frac{R_T}{R_0}=\frac{1440}{120}=12[/latex] [latex] \alpha \Delta T=11 [/latex] [latex]\Delta T=2444.44^{\circ}C[/latex] [latex] T=2444.44^{\circ}C+26^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]T=2470.44^{\circ}C [/latex] Therefore, ON state temperature of filament [latex]= 2470.44^{\circ}C[/latex]

question: Question 93 A combination of 1 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor with an initial voltage [latex]v_c(0)=-2V[/latex] in series with a 100 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor is connected to a 20 mA ideal dc current source by operating both switches at t=0s as shown. Which of the following graphs shown in the options approximates the voltage [latex]v_s[/latex] across the current source over the next few seconds ?
solution: Given [latex]C=1\mu F, V_c(0)=-2V[/latex],  [latex]R=100\Omega , I=20mA[/latex]. Circuit fot the given condition at time [latex]t \gt 0[/latex] is shown below: Applying KVL, we have,[latex]V_s(s)=\left ( \frac{-2}{s} \right )+\frac{I}{s} \left ( R+\frac{I}{Cs} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{s}\left [ -2+IR+\frac{I}{Cs} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{s}\left [ (IR-2) +\frac{I}{Cs}\right ] [/latex] Putting values of R, C and I, we get, [latex]V_s(s)=\frac{1}{s}\left [ (20 \times 10^{-3} \times 200-2)+\left ( \frac{20 \times 10^{-3}}{10^{-6}} \right ) \times \frac{1}{s} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{s}\left [ (2-2)+20 \times 10^3 \times \frac{1}{s} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{20 \times 10^3}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_s(s)=\frac{20 \times 10^3}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]V_s(t)=20000 t u(t) [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_s(s)=(20000)tu(t) [/latex] Which is equation of a straight line passing through origin. Hence option (C) is correct.

question:
Question 94 The three circuit elements shown in the figure are part of an electric circuit. The
total power absorbed by the three circuit elements in watts is _____.
solution: Given electrical circuit is shown below: Applying KCL at node, current through 15V voltage source =2 A Power absorbed by 100 V voltage source = 10x100=1000 Watt. Power absorbed by 80 V voltage source =-(80x8)=-640 Watts and power absorbed by 15 V voltage source = -(15x2)=-30 Watt. Therefore,  total power absorbed by the three circuit element=(100-640-30_ watts =330 Watts

question:
Question 95 The following arrangement consists of an ideal transformer and an attenuator
which attenuates by a factor of 0.8. An ac voltage [latex]V_{WX1}[/latex] = 100 V is applied
across WX to get an open circuit voltage [latex]V_{YZ1}[/latex] across YZ. Next, an ac voltage[latex]V_{YZ2}[/latex] = 100 V is applied across YZ to get an open circuit voltage [latex]V_{WX2}[/latex] across WX. Then,[latex]V_{YZ1}/V_{WX1},V_{WX2}/V_{YZ2}[/latex] are respectively,
solution: [latex]V_{YZ_1}=100\times 1.25 \times 0.8 =100 [/latex] In second case when 100 V is applied at YZ terminals, this whole 100 V will appear across the secondary winding, Hence, [latex]V_{WX_2}=\frac{100}{1.25}=80V [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \frac{V_{YZ_1}}{V_{WX_1}}=\frac{100}{100}[/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{WX_2}}{V_{YZ_2}}=\frac{80}{100}[/latex]

question:
Question 96 Two magnetically uncoupled inductive coils have Q factors [latex]q_1 \; and \; q_2[/latex] at the chosen
operating frequency. Their respective resistances are [latex]R_1 \; and \; R_2[/latex]. When connected
in series, their effective Q factor at the same operating frequency is
solution: [latex]q_1=\frac{\omega L_1}{R_1} [/latex] [latex]L_1=\frac{q_1R_1}{\omega }[/latex] Similarly, [latex]L_2=\frac{q_2R_2}{\omega } [/latex] [latex]Q=\frac{\omega (L_1+L_2)}{R_1+R_2}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{q_1R_1+q_2R_2}{R_1+R_2}[/latex]

question: Question 97 Three capacitors [latex]C_1, C_2 \; and \; C_3[/latex] whose values are 10 [latex]\mu[/latex]F, 5 [latex]\mu[/latex]F, and 2 [latex]\mu[/latex]F respectively, have breakdown voltages of 10 V, 5 V and 2 V respectively. For the interconnection shown below, the maximum safe voltage in Volts that can be applied across the combination, and the corresponding total charge in [latex]\mu[/latex]C stored in the effective capacitance across the terminals are respectively,
solution: [latex]Q=CV [/latex] [latex]Q_1=C_1V_1 =10 \times 10^{-6} \times 10=100\mu C [/latex] [latex]Q_2=C_2V_2 =5 \times 10^{-6} \times 5=25\mu C [/latex] [latex]Q_3=C_3V_3 =2 \times 10^{-6} \times 2=4\mu C [/latex] Capacitor [latex]C_2 \; and \; C_3[/latex] are in series. In series charge is same. So, maximum charge on [latex]C_2 \; and \; C_3[/latex] will be minimum of [latex](Q_2,Q_3)=min(25\mu C,4\mu C)=4\mu C=Q_{23}[/latex]. In series the equivalent capacitance of [latex]C_2 \; and \; C_3[/latex] is [latex]C_{23}=\frac{C_2C_3}{C_2+C_3}=\frac{5 \times 2}{5+2}=\frac{10}{7}\mu F [/latex] So, equivalent voltage, [latex]V_{23}=\frac{Q_{23}}{C_{23}}=\frac{4 \times 10^{-6}}{\frac{10}{7} \times 10^{-6}}=\frac{28}{10}2.8V [/latex] In parallel, the voltage is same. [latex]V_1=V_{23}=2.8V [/latex] Change in capacitor [latex]C_1 [/latex] [latex]Q_1=C_1V_1 =10 \times 10^{-6}\times 2.8=28\mu C [/latex] In parallel, the total charge [latex]Q=Q_1+Q_{23} [/latex] [latex]Q=4+28=32\mu C[/latex]

question: Question 98 In the circuit shown below, if the source voltage [latex]V_{s}=100\angle 53.13^{\circ}[/latex]V then the Thevenin's equivalent voltage in Volts as seen by the load resistance [latex]R_L[/latex] is
solution: [latex]V_{L_1}=\left ( \frac{j4}{3+j4} \right )100\angle 53.13^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \;\;=80\angle 90^{\circ}V [/latex] [latex]V_{Th}=10V_{L_1}=800\angle 90^{\circ}V[/latex]

question:
Question 99 Consider a delta connection of resistors and its equivalent star connection as
shown below. If all elements of the delta connection are scaled by a factor [latex]k , k\gt 0[/latex], the elements of the corresponding star equivalent will be scaled by a factor of
solution: [latex]R_A=\frac{R_bR_c}{R_a+R_b+R_c} [/latex] [latex]R'_a=kR_a [/latex] [latex]R'_b=kR_b [/latex] [latex]R'_c=kR_c [/latex] [latex]R'_A=\frac{kR_b\cdot kR_c}{kR_a+kR_b+kR_c} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{k^2R_bR_c}{k(R_a+R_b+R_c)} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=k \times \frac{R_bR_c}{R_a+R_b+R_c} [/latex] [latex]R'_A=kR_A[/latex]

question: Question 100 A source [latex]v_{s}(t)=V \cos 100\pi t[/latex] has an internal impedance of [latex](4+j3)\Omega[/latex]. If a purely resistive load connected to this source has to extract the maximum power out of the source, its value in [latex]\Omega[/latex] should be
solution: Using maximum power transfer theorem, [latex]R_L=|Z|=|4-j3| [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\sqrt{4^2+3^2}=5\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 101 In the circuit shown, the three voltmeter readings are [latex]V_1=[/latex]220 V , [latex]V_2=[/latex]122 V , [latex]V_3=[/latex]136 V. If [latex]R_L=5\Omega[/latex], the approximate power consumption in the load is
solution: Given, [latex]R_L= 5\Omega [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; \cos \phi =\frac{R_L}{|Z|} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;|Z|=\frac{5}{0.45}=11.11 [/latex] Power consumed by load, [latex]P_L=\left ( \frac{V_3}{|Z|} \right )^2R_L [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\left ( \frac{136}{11.11} \right )^2 \times 5 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=749.1\approx 750W[/latex]

question: Question 102 In the circuit shown, the three voltmeter readings are [latex]V_1=[/latex]220 V , [latex]V_2=[/latex]122 V , [latex]V_3=[/latex]136 V. The power factor of the load is
solution: [latex]V_1^2=V_2^2+V_3^2+2V_2V_3 \cos \phi [/latex] [latex](220)^2=(122)^2+(136)^2+2 \times 122 \times 136 \times \cos \phi [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; \cos \phi =0.45[/latex]

question:
Question 103 With 10 V dc connected at port A in the linear nonreciprocal two-port network shown below, the following
were observed: (i) 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 3 A (ii) 2.5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 2 A For the same network, with 6 V dc connected at port A, 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port
B draws 7/3 A. If 8 V dc is connected to port A, the open circuit voltage at port B is
solution: [latex](i) [/latex] [latex]V_1=10V,V_2=3V,  I_2=-3A [/latex] [latex]V_1=AV_2-BI_2 [/latex] [latex]10=3A+3B[/latex] [latex] (ii) V_2=5V, I_2=-2A [/latex] [latex]10=5A+2B [/latex] [latex]A=\frac{10}{9} [/latex] [latex]B=\frac{20}{9} [/latex] Given,   [latex] V_1=8V [/latex] [latex](V_2)_{OC}=? [/latex] [latex]I_2=0[/latex] [latex] V_1=AV_2-BI_2 [/latex] [latex]8=A(V_2)_{OC}-0 [/latex] [latex](V_2)_{OC}=\frac{8}{A}=\frac{8}{10/9}=7.2V[/latex]

question:
Question 104 With 10 V dc connected at port A in the linear nonreciprocal two-port network shown below, the following
were observed: (i) 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 3 A (ii) 2.5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 2 A With 10 V dc connected at port A, the current drawn by 7 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B is
solution: Given, [latex]V_1=10V, V_2=(-7I_2) [/latex] [latex]V_1=AV_2-BI_2 [/latex] [latex]10=-7I_2A-BI_2 [/latex] [latex]=-\frac{70}{9}I_2-\frac{20}{9}I_2 [/latex] [latex]I_2=-1A [/latex] -ve sign is signifies that current is drawn.

question:
Question 105 Assuming both the voltage sources are in phase, the value of R for which maximum
power is transferred from circuit A to circuit B is
solution: [latex]I=\frac{7}{R+2} [/latex] [latex]V=10-2I [/latex] [latex]\;\;=10-\frac{14}{R+2}=\frac{10R+6}{R+2} [/latex] Power transferred from circuit A to circuit B [latex]P=VI [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{10R+6}{R+2} \times \frac{7}{R+2} [/latex] For P to be maximum [latex]\frac{dP}{dR}=0 [/latex] [latex](R+2)^2(10)-(10R+6)\times 2 (R+2)=0 [/latex] [latex]5R^2+20R+20-10R^2+26R+12=0 [/latex] [latex]5R^2+6R=8[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;R=0.8\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 106 If [latex]V_{A}-V_{B}[/latex] =6V then [latex]V_{C}-V_{D}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]V_A-V_B=2I [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 2I=6 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I=3A [/latex] [latex]V_C+2+1 \times I=V_D [/latex] [latex]V_C-V_D=-2-3=-5V[/latex]

question:
Question 107 In the following figure, [latex]C_1 \; and \; C_2[/latex] are ideal capacitors. [latex]C_1[/latex] has been charged to
12 V before the ideal switch S is closed at t=0. The current i(t) for all t is
solution: Circuit is s-domain By applying KVL, [latex]\frac{12}{s}+\frac{I(s)}{s}\left ( \frac{1}{C_1} +\frac{1}{C_2}\right )=0[/latex] [latex] I(s)=-\frac{12C_1C_2}{C_1+C_2}=k(constant)[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; i(t)=k\delta (t) [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Current [latex]i(t)[/latex] is an implulse function.

question:
Question 108 The average power delivered to an impedance [latex](4-j3)\Omega[/latex] by a current
5cos(100[latex]\pi[/latex]t+100)A is
solution: [latex]i=5 \cos (100 \pi t +100^{\circ})A [/latex] [latex]\;\;=5\angle 100^{\circ}A [/latex] [latex]Z=(4-j3)\Omega [/latex] [latex]\;\;=5\angle -36.87^{\circ}\Omega [/latex] [latex]V=iZ=25\angle 63.13^{\circ}V [/latex] The average power is [latex]P=\frac{1}{2}V_mI_m \cos \phi[/latex] [latex] \;\;=\frac{1}{2} \times 25 \times 5 \times \cos (36.87^{\circ}) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{2} \times 25 \times 5 \times \frac{4}{5}=50W [/latex] Alternate Method: [latex]P=|I_{rms}|^2R [/latex] [latex]P=\left ( \frac{5}{\sqrt{2}} \right )^2 4=50W[/latex]

question: Question 109 A two-phase load draws the following phase currents : [latex]i_{1}(t)=I_{m}sin(\omega t-\phi _{1})[/latex], [latex]i_{2}(t)=I_{m}cos(\omega t-\phi _{2})[/latex]. These currents are balanced if [latex]\phi _{1}[/latex] is equal to.
solution: In two phase, current are balanced if phase difference is [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]. [latex]i_1(t)=I_m \sin (\omega t-\phi _1) [/latex] [latex]i_2(t)=I_m \sin (\omega t-\phi _2+90^{\circ}) [/latex] Phase difference is [latex]90^{\circ},[/latex] [latex] \omega t-\phi _2+90^{\circ}-(\omega t-\phi _1)=90^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]\phi _1-\phi _2=0 [/latex] [latex]\phi _1=\phi _2[/latex]

question: Question 110 The impedance looking into nodes 1 and 2 in the given circuit is
solution: To find thevenin impedance across node 1 and node 2. Connect a 1 V source and find the current through voltage source. Then, [latex]Z_{Th}=\frac{1}{I_{Th}} [/latex] By applying KCL at node B and A [latex]i_{AB}+99i_{b}=I_{Th} [/latex] [latex]i_b==i_A+i_{AB}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; i_b-i_A+99i_b=I_{Th} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; 100i_b-i_A=I_{Th}\;...(i) [/latex] By applying KVL in outer loop [latex]10 \times 10^3i_b=1 [/latex] [latex]i_b=10^{-4}A [/latex] and [latex] 10 \times 10^{3}i_b=-100i_A [/latex] [latex]i_A=-100i_b [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  From equation (i), [latex]100i_b+100i_b=I_{Th} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_{Th}=200i_b [/latex] [latex]\;\;=200 \times 10^{-4}=0.02[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\;Z_{Th}=\frac{1}{I_{Th}}=\frac{1}{0.02}=50\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 111 In the circuit shown below, the current through the inductor is
solution: Apply KCL node at 'A' so, current flowing through [latex]1\Omega[/latex] is [latex](1-I_2)[/latex] Applying KVL in ABCD loop, [latex]1\angle 0-1\angle 0+1(1-I_2)-jI_2=0 [/latex] [latex]I_2=\frac{1}{1+j}[/latex]

question: Question 112 An RLC circuit with relevant data is given below. The current [latex]I_C[/latex] in the figure above is
solution: Using KCL, [latex]-I_s+I_{RL}+I_C=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_C=I_s-I_{RL} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\sqrt{2}\angle \frac{\pi}{4}-\sqrt{2}\angle -\frac{\pi}{4} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=2\angle 90^{\circ}=+j2A[/latex]

question: Question 113 An RLC circuit with relevant data is given below. The power dissipated in the resistor R is
solution: Power supplied by the source [latex]=V_sI_s \cos \phi [/latex] Where,  [latex]\phi =[/latex] angle between [latex]V_s[/latex] and [latex]I_s \;=\; \pi/4[/latex] Inductor and capacitor do not consume power. Therefore, power dissipated in R = Power supplied by the source [latex]P_R=V_SI_S \cos \phi [/latex] [latex]\;\;=1 \times \sqrt{2} \times \cos \frac{\pi}{4} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\sqrt{2} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=1 W[/latex]

question:
Question 114 In the circuit given below, the value of R required for the transfer of maximum
power to the load having a resistance of 3[latex]\Omega[/latex] is
solution: For maximum power transfer to the load, the source resistance must be minimum i.e. zero. So, [latex]R=0\Omega[/latex].

question:
Question 115 The voltage applied to a circuit is [latex]100 \sqrt{2} cos (100 \pi t)[/latex] volts and the circuit draws
a current of [latex]10 \sqrt{2} sin(100 \pi t+\pi/4)[/latex] amperes. Taking the voltage as the reference
phasor, the phasor representation of the current in amperes is
solution: [latex]V(t)=100\sqrt{2} \cos (100 \pi t) [/latex] Voltage represented in phasor form: [latex]V_{ph}=V_{rms}\angle \phi [/latex] [latex]V_{ph}=\frac{100\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}}\angle 0^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]i(t)=10\sqrt{2} \sin \left ( 100 \pi t +\frac{\pi}{4} \right ) [/latex] [latex]i(t)=10\sqrt{2} \cos \left ( 100 \pi t +\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\pi}{2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]I_{ph}=\frac{10\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}}\angle\left ( \frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\pi}{2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=10\angle \left ( -\frac{\pi}{4} \right )A[/latex]

question: Question 116 The r.m.s value of the current i(t) in the circuit shown below is
solution: [latex]V_s=1 \sin t\equiv V_m \sin \omega t [/latex] [latex]V_m=1 V[/latex] and  [latex] \omega =1[/latex] rad/sec Impedance of the branch containing inductor and capacitor [latex]Z=j(X_L-X_C)[/latex] [latex] \;\;=j\left ( \omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=j\left ( 1 times 1 -\frac{1}{1 times 1} \right )=0 [/latex] So, this branch is short circuit and the whole current flow through it [latex] i(t)=\frac{1.0 \sin t}{1}=1.0 \sin t [/latex] rms value of the current [latex]=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}A[/latex]

question:
Question 117 The L-C circuit shown in the figure has an inductance L=1mH and a
capacitance C=[latex]\mu[/latex]F. The initial current through the inductor is zero, while the initial capacitor voltage
is 100 V. The switch is closed at t=0. The current i through the circuit
solution: Initial current through the inductor is zeroand capacitor voltage is charged upto voltage [latex]V_c(0^-)=100V[/latex] As current through inductor and voltage across capacitor can not change abruptly So, after closing the switch, [latex]i_L(0^+)=i_L(0^-)=0 [/latex] and [latex] V_c(0^+)=V_c(0^-)=100V [/latex] The circuit id s-domain [latex]I(s)=\frac{100/s}{\left ( sL+\frac{1}{sC} \right )} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100}{L}\left ( \frac{1}{s^2+\frac{1}{LC}} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=100\sqrt{\frac{C}{L}}\left ( \frac{1/\sqrt{LC}}{s^2+(1/\sqrt{LC})^2} \right ) [/latex] taking inverse laplace transform [latex]i(t)=L^{-1}[I(s)] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=100\sqrt{\frac{C}{L}} \sin \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}t [/latex] [latex]\;\;=100 \times \sqrt{\frac{10 \times 10^3}{1 \times 10^{-3}}}\times [/latex]  [latex]\sin\left ( \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 \times 10^{-3} \times 10 \times 10^{-6}}} \right ) [/latex] [latex]i(t)=10\sin (10^4 t)A[/latex]

question:
Question 118 The two-port network P shown in the figure has ports 1 and 2, denoted by
terminals (a,b) and (c,d) respectively. It has an impedance matrix Z with
parameters denoted by [latex]Z_{ij}[/latex]. A 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor is connected in series with the network
at port 1 as shown in the figure. The impedance matrix of the modified two-port
network (shown as a dashed box ) is
solution: [latex]V_1^{ab}=Z_{11}I_1+Z_{12}I_2[/latex] [latex] V_2=Z_{21}I_1+Z_{22}I_2 [/latex] As,  [latex] 1\Omega[/latex] resistor is connected in series with the network as port-1. [latex] V_2[/latex] does not get affected, [latex]V_1^{ef}=V_1^{ab}+I_1 \times 1[/latex] [latex]\;\;=Z_{11}I_1+Z_{12}I_2+I_1 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=(Z_{11}+1)I_1+Z_{12}I_2 [/latex] Modified Z-parameter [latex] =\begin{bmatrix} Z_{11}+1 & Z_{12}\\ Z_{21} &Z_{22} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question:
Question 119 If the 12 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor draws a current of 1 A as shown in the figure, the value of
resistance R is
solution: Assuming voltage of the node [latex]V_a[/latex] [latex]V_a=1 \times 12 =12V [/latex] Applying KCL, [latex] -2+1+I=0 [/latex] [latex]I=1A [/latex] [latex]I=\frac{V_a-6}{R} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{12-6}{R}=\frac{6}{R} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;I=\frac{6}{R} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; R=6\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 120 If the electrical circuit of figure (b) is an equivalent of the coupled tank system
of figure (a), then
solution: In such system, volumetric flow rate C is analogous to current and pressure is analogous to voltage The hydraulic capacitance due to storage in gravity field is defined as [latex]C=\frac{A}{\rho g}[/latex] where,  A= Area of the tank [latex]\rho[/latex]= Density of the fluid g= Acceleration due to gravity The hydraulic capacitance is represented by A and C. Liquid trying to flow out of a container,can meet with resistance in several ways. If the outlet is a pipe, the friction between the liquid and the pile wall produces resistance to flow. Such resistance is represented by B and D.

options.A: A, B are resistances and C, D capacitances
options.B: A, C are resistances and B, D capacitances
options.C: A, B are capacitances and C, D resistances
options.D: A, C are capacitances and B, D resistances

question: Question 121 As shown in the figure, a 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance is connected across a source that has a load line v+i=100. The current through the resistance is
solution: A resistor has linear characteristics i.e. [latex]V=Ri[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; V=i [/latex] Load line, [latex]V+i=100 [/latex] [latex]i+i=100 [/latex] current through resistance, [latex]i=\frac{100}{2}=50A[/latex]

question: Question 122 The switch in the circuit has been closed for a long time. It is opened at t = 0. At t =[latex]0^+[/latex], the current through the 1 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor is
solution: As the switch has been closed for a long time, the circuit is in steady state. At steadystate, capacitor is open circuit, Using KVL, [latex]5-I-4I=0 I=1A [/latex] [latex]V_c(0^-)=4 \times 1=4V [/latex] As the voltage across capacitorcan not change abruptly, So, [latex]V_c(0^+)=V_c(0^-)=4V [/latex] Circuit at [latex]t=0^+[/latex] Current through capacitor at [latex]t=0^+ [/latex] [latex]I_c(0^+)=\frac{4}{4}=1A[/latex]

question: Question 123 For the circuit given above, the Thevenin's voltage across the terminals A and B is
solution: To calculate thevenin's volatage, terminal A-B are kept open. Applying source transformation, voltage sorce is transformed into current source. Applying source transformation current source is transformed into voltage souce. Applying KVL, (I is assumed to be in mA) [latex]\frac{5}{2}-I-3V_{OC}-I=0\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]I=\frac{V_{OC}}{I}\;\;...(ii) [/latex] Put value of I in equation (i), [latex]\frac{5}{2}-5V_{OC}=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; V_{OC}=0.5 V[/latex]

question:
Question 124 For the circuit given above, the Thevenin's resistance across the terminals A and
B is
solution: To calculate thevenin's resistance 5 V source is short-circuited and [latex]V_{dc}[/latex] source is connected at terminals A and B [latex]R_{th}=\frac{V_{dc}}{I}[/latex] [latex] V_{AB}=V_{dc} [/latex] and assuming [latex]I \; and \; I_1[/latex] in mA. Current through [latex]1k\Omega[/latex] resistance [latex]I_1=\frac{V_{dc}}{1}=V_{dc} [/latex] [latex]V_{AB}=V_{dc}[/latex] [latex] V_x=2||2\times (I-I_1) [/latex] [latex]V_x=I-I_1=I-V_{dc}\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]V_x=3V_{AB}+I_1 [/latex] [latex]\;\;3V_{dc}+V_{dc}=4V_{dc}\;...(ii)[/latex] Comparing equation (i) and (ii), [latex]I-V_{dc}=4V_{dc} [/latex] [latex]R_{th}=\frac{V_{dc}}{I}=\frac{1}{5}=0.2\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 125 For the circuit shown, find out the current flowing through the 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance.
Also identify the changes to be made to double the current through the 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex]
resistance.
solution: Voltage across [latex]2\Omega[/latex] resistance [latex]=V_s=4V[/latex] Current through [latex]2\Omega[/latex] resistance [latex]\frac{V_s}{R}=\frac{4}{2}=2A[/latex] Current cource has no effect, when connected across voltage source. So, to double current through [latex]2\Omega[/latex] resistance, voltage source is doubled i.e. [latex]V-s=8V[/latex]

question: Question 126 The equivalent capacitance of the input loop of the circuit shown is
solution: Applying KVL, [latex]V_{in}-i_1(1+1)-50i_1(-jX_C)=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; v_{in}=i_1[2-j50V_C] [/latex] Input impedance [latex]=\frac{V_{in}}{i_1}=2-j50X_C[/latex] As imaginary part is negative, input impedance has equivalent capacitive reactance [latex]X_{C\;eq.} [/latex] [latex]X_{C\;eq.}=50X_C [/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{\omega C_{eq.}}=\frac{50}{\omega C}=\frac{50}{\omega \times 100}=\frac{1}{2 \omega} [/latex] [latex]C_{eq.}=2\mu F[/latex]

question:
Question 127 In the figure shown, all elements used are ideal. For time [latex]t \lt 0[/latex], [latex]S_1[/latex] remained closed
and [latex]S_2[/latex] open. At t=0, [latex]S_1[/latex] is opened and [latex]S_2[/latex] is closed. If the voltage [latex]V_{C2}[/latex] across the
capacitor [latex]C_2[/latex] at t=0 is zero, the voltage across the capacitor combination at
t=[latex]0^+[/latex] will be
solution: At [latex]t=0^-, S_1[/latex] is closed, [latex]S_2[/latex] is open [latex]C_1[/latex] gets charged upto 3 V Charge stored in [latex]C_1[/latex] [latex]Q_0=C_1V=1 \times 3=3C[/latex] Voltage across [latex]C_2[/latex] is zero at [latex]t=0^-[/latex], so no charge is stored in [latex]C_2[/latex]. At [latex]t \gt 0,\;S_1[/latex] is open and [latex]S_2[/latex] is closed. Charge stored ([latex]Q_0[/latex]) initially in [latex]C_2[/latex] gets redistributed between  [latex]C_1[/latex] and [latex]C_2[/latex]. Let charge stored in [latex]C_1=Q_1[/latex] Charge stored in [latex]C_2=Q_1[/latex] According to conservation of charge [latex]Q_1+Q_2=Q_0=3\;\;...(i)[/latex] Voltage across [latex]C_1[/latex] =Voltage across [latex]C_2[/latex] [latex]\frac{Q_1}{C_1}=\frac{Q_2}{C_2} [/latex] [latex]\rightarrow \;\; \frac{Q_1}{1}=\frac{Q_2}{2} [/latex] [latex]Q_2=2Q_1\;\;...(ii) [/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii) we get [latex]Q_1=1 C [/latex] and [latex] Q_2 =2 C [/latex] Voltage across combination [latex]= \frac{Q_1}{C_1}=\frac{1}{1}=1[/latex]

question:
Question 128 How many 200 W/220 V incandescent lamps connected in series would consume
the same total power as a single 100 W/220 V incandescent lamp ?
solution: Let resistance of a single incandescent lamp=R. Power consumed by a single lamp, P=200W. When connected across voltage, V=220V. So, [latex]P=\frac{V^2}{R}\; \Rightarrow \; 200=\frac{220^2}{R} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; R=242\Omega [/latex] Let, n number of lamps are connected in series across voltage V=200V. So total resistance of lamps [latex] R_{eq.}=nR=242n[/latex] Total power consumed, [latex]P=\frac{V^2}{R_{eq.}} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 100=\frac{220^2}{242n} \Rightarrow \; n=2[/latex]

question: Question 129 The current through the 2 k[latex]\Omega[/latex] resistance in the circuit shown is
solution: Bridge is balanced i.i. node C and node D are at same potential. Therefore, no current flows through [latex]2 k\Omega[/latex] resistor.

question:
Question 130 The current i(t) sketched in the figure flows through a initially uncharged 0.3 nF
capacitor. The capacitor charged upto 5[latex]\mu[/latex]s, as per the current profile given in the figure,
is connected across an inductor of 0.6 mH. Then the value of voltage across the
capacitor after 1[latex]\mu[/latex]s will approximately be
solution: Capacitor charge upto [latex]5\mu s[/latex], so total charge stored in capacitor = Q = 13 nC. Voltage across the capacitor before connecting to inductor [latex]V_0=\frac{Q}{C}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{13 \times 10^{-9}}{0.3 \times 10^{-9}}=43.33V [/latex] Voltage across the capacitor at time [latex]t [/latex] [latex]V_c(t)[/latex] at [latex]t= 1\mu s [/latex] [latex]V_c(t)|_{t=1\mu s}=[V_0 \cos \omega _0 t]_{t=1\mu s}[/latex] [latex] \omega _0t=\frac{1}{\sqrt{0.6 \times 10^3 \times 0.3 \times 10^{-9}}}\times 1 \times 10^{-6}[/latex] [latex]\;\; =2.357 rad=135^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]V_c(t)|_{t=1\mu s}=43.33 \times \cos 135^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \;\;\approx -30.6 V[/latex]

question:
Question 131 The current i(t) sketched in the figure flows through a initially uncharged 0.3 nF
capacitor. The charge stored in the capacitor at t=5 [latex]\mu[/latex]s, will be
solution: Charged stored in the capcitor =Area under i-t curve [latex]Q=A_1+A_2[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{2}(2 \times 10^{-6})\times (4 \times 10^{-3})[/latex]  [latex]+\frac{1}{2} (4+2)\times 10^{-3}\times (5-2)\times 10^{-6} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\left ( 4+\frac{6 \times 3}{2} \right )\times 10^[-9]=13nC[/latex]

question: Question 132 In the circuit shown in the figure, the value of the current i will be given by
solution: By KVL in loop-1, [latex]5-i_1-i_1=0 [/latex] [latex]i_1=2.5A [/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \; V_a=2.5V [/latex] By KVL in loop-2, [latex]4V_{ab}=3i_2+i_2 [/latex] [latex]i_2=V_{ab} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_b=1 \times i_2=V_{ab} [/latex] [latex]V_b=V_a-V_b [/latex] [latex]V_b=\frac{V_a}{2}=\frac{2.5}{2}=1.25V [/latex] [latex]i_2=V_{ab}=V_b [/latex] [latex]i_2=1.25A[/latex]

question: Question 134 The resonant frequency for the given circuit will be
solution: Input impedance [latex]z=j\omega L+R||\frac{1}{j\omega C} [/latex] [latex]z=j\omega L+\frac{R}{1+j\omega RC} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; z=j0.1\omega +\frac{1}{1+j\omega } \times \frac{1-j\omega }{1-j\omega } [/latex] [latex]\;\;=j0.1\omega +\frac{1-j\omega }{1+\omega ^2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{1+\omega ^2}+j \times \left ( 0.1\omega -\frac{\omega }{1+\omega ^2} \right ) [/latex] At resonance, imaginary part must be zero. [latex]0.1\omega - \frac{\omega }{1+\omega ^2}=0 [/latex] [latex]0.1=\frac{1 }{1+\omega ^2} [/latex] [latex]\omega ^2+1=10 [/latex] [latex]\omega ^2=9 [/latex] [latex]\omega =3 rad/sec[/latex]

solution: Convention: (when branch [latex]b_j[/latex] leaves away from node [latex]N_i[/latex] ) (when branch [latex]b_j[/latex] enters node [latex]N_i[/latex]) Given node incidence matrix eg.: Branch [latex]b_1[/latex] enter [latex]N_3[/latex] and leaves [latex]N_1[/latex] The oriented network graph Using KVL, in loop containing branches   [latex]b_1,b_3[/latex] and  [latex]b_6[/latex] [latex]v_1-v_6-v_3=0[/latex] In loop containing branches [latex]b_4,b_5[/latex] and  [latex]b_6[/latex] [latex]v_4+v_5-v_6=0[/latex]

Question 139 A 3 V DC supply with an internal resistance of 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] supplies a passive non-linear
resistance characterized by the relation [latex]V_{NL}=I^{2}_{NL}[/latex]. The power dissipated in the non linear resistance is
solution: [latex]V_{NL}=I_{NL}^2\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]V_{NL}=E-I_{NL}R [/latex] where, [latex]E=3V [/latex] and [latex]R=2\Omega [/latex] [latex]V_{NL}=3-2I_{NL}=I_{NL}^2 [/latex] [latex]I_{NL}^2+2I_{NL}-3=0 [/latex] [latex]I_{NL}=-3A [/latex] or [latex] 1 A [/latex] -3 A is rejected, because the non-linear resistor is passive and the only active element in the circuit is 3 V DC supply. Which is supplying the power to the resistor. So, [latex]I_{NL}=1 A [/latex] Power dissipated in the non-linear resistor [latex] =V_{NL}I_{NL}=I_{NL}^2I_{NL}[/latex] [latex] =I_{NL}^3=1^3=1W[/latex]

Angle of [latex]V_{YX}=180^{\circ}+2 \tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{X_C}{R} \right )  [/latex] When, R=0 [latex]\angle V_{YX}=180^{\circ}+2 \tan ^{-1}(\infty ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=180^{\circ}+2 \times 90^{\circ}=360^{\circ} [/latex] when  [latex] R=\infty [/latex] [latex]\angle V_{YX}=180^{\circ}+2 \tan ^{-1}(0 )=180^{\circ} [/latex] on the basis of above analysis, the locus of [latex]V_{YX}[/latex] is drawn below:

[latex]Re[Y]=\frac{R}{R^2+\left ( \omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C} \right )^2} [/latex] For any value of [latex]\omega[/latex] , the real part is always positive. When, [latex]\omega L=\frac{1}{ \omega C} [/latex] At,  [latex] \omega_0=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} [/latex] [latex]Re[Y]=\frac{1}{R} [/latex] [latex]I_m(Y)=\frac{-\left ( \omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C} \right )}{R^2+\left ( \omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C} \right )^2} =\frac{\left ( \frac{1}{\omega C}-\omega L \right )}{R^2+\left ( \omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C} \right )^2} [/latex] At, [latex] \omega_0=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}[/latex] Imaginary part of zero [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; Im(Y)=0 [/latex] For, [latex] 0 \lt \omega \lt \omega _0 [/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{\omega C} \gt \omega L [/latex] Therefore,  [latex]Im[Y] \gt 0 [/latex] For, [latex] \omega _0 \lt \omega \lt \infty [/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{\omega C}\lt \omega L [/latex] Therefore, [latex]Im[Y] \lt 0[/latex] On the basis of above analysis, the admittance locus is
