question:
Question 143 In the figure, transformer [latex]T_1[/latex] has two secondaries, all three windings having the
same number of turns and with polarities as indicated. One secondary is shorted
by a 10 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor R, and the other by a 15 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor. The switch SW is opened
(t=0) when the capacitor is charged to 5 V with the left plate as positive. At
t=0+ the voltage [latex]V_P[/latex] and current [latex]I_R[/latex] are
solution: All the three windings has same number of turns, so magnitude of induced emf's in all the three windings will be same i.e. [latex]|V_P|=|V_s|=|V_T|[/latex] Polarity of the winding is decided on the basis of dot-convention. As capacitor is carged to 5V with left plate as positive So, [latex]T_1[/latex] is positive w.r.t. [latex]T_2[/latex] [latex]V_T=V_{T_1}-V{T_2}=5V[/latex] As [latex]T_2[/latex] has negative polarity. So [latex]P_1[/latex] has negative polarity. Therefore , [latex]V_P=V_{P_1}-V{P_2}=-5V[/latex] Similarly,  [latex]S_1[/latex] has negative polarity So, [latex]V_s=V_{s_1}-V{s_2}=-5V[/latex] [latex]I_R=\frac{V_s}{R}=\frac{-5}{10}=-0.5A[/latex]

options.B: very large voltage, very large current

question:
Question 144 An energy meter connected to an immersion heater (resistive) operating on an
AC 230 V, 50 Hz, AC single phase source reads 2.3 units (kWh) in 1 hour. The
heater is removed from the supply and now connected to a 400 V peak to peak square
wave source of 150 Hz. The power in kW dissipated by the heater will be
solution: Assuming resistance of the heater=R (i)  When heater connected to 230 V, 50 Hz source, energy consumed by the heater = 2.3 units or 2.3 kWh in 1 hour Power consumed by the heater [latex]=\frac{energy}{time \;eriod}=\frac{2.3kWh}{1 \; hour}[/latex] [latex]P_1=2.3 kW[/latex] rms value of the input voltage [latex] =V_{rms}=230V [/latex] [latex]P_1=\frac{V_{rms}^2}{R} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 2.3 \times 10^3=\frac{230^2}{R} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; R=23\Omega [/latex] (ii) When heater connected to 400 V (peak to peak) square wave source of 150Hz [latex]V_{rms}[/latex] value of the input voltage [/latex] [latex]V_{rms}=\left [ \frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}V^2 \; dt \right ]^{1/2} [/latex] [latex]V_{rms}=\left [ \frac{1}{T}\left \{ \int_{0}^{T/2} 200^2 \; dt+ \int_{T/2}^{T} (-200)^2 \; dt\right \} \right ]^{1/2} [/latex] [latex]V_{rms}=200V [/latex] [latex]P_2=\frac{V_{rms}^2}{R}=\frac{200^2}{23}\times 10^{-3}kW =1.739kW[/latex]

question:
Question 145 An ideal capacitor is charged to a voltage [latex]V_{0}[/latex] and connected at t=0 across an
ideal inductor L. (The circuit now consists of a capacitor and inductor alone). If
we let [latex]\omega _{0}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}[/latex], the voltage across the capacitor at time [latex]t \gt 0[/latex] is given by
solution: Voltage across capacitor will discharge through inductor upto voltage across the capcitor becomes zero. During thos period , electrostatic energy stored in capacitor is transferred into magnetic energy which is stored in inductor. Now, inductor will start charging capacitor, magnetic energy in inductor is converted into electostatic energy in capacitor. Expression for [latex]V_c(t)[/latex] can be obtained in s-domain. As capacitor is charged initially to voltage [latex]V_0[/latex], then representation of capacitor in s-domain As current through the inductor is zero at t=0, then The circuit at [latex]t \gt 0[/latex] [latex]I(s)=\frac{V_0/s}{\frac{1}{sC}+sL}=\frac{V_0}{s^2L+\frac{1}{C}} I(s)=\frac{V_0}{L}\left ( \frac{1}{s^2+\frac{1}{LC}} \right ) Voltage across capacitor =voltage across inductor [latex]=V(s),[/latex] [latex] V(s)=I(s) \times (sL) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{V_0}{L}\left ( \frac{1}{s^2+\frac{1}{LC}} \right ) \times (sL) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=V_0\left ( \frac{s}{s^2+\frac{1}{LC}} \right ) [/latex] As, [latex] \omega _0=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}[/latex] [latex] V(s)=V_0\left ( \frac{s}{s^2+\omega _0^2} \right ) [/latex] Voltage across the capacitor [latex]=V(t)=L^{-1}[V(s)][/latex] [latex]\;\;=L^{-1}\left ( \frac{V_0s}{s^2+\omega _0^2} \right ) [/latex] [latex]V(t)=V_0 \cos \omega _0 t [/latex] where, [latex] \omega _0=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}[/latex]

question:
Question 146 The circuit shown in the figure is energized by a sinusoidal voltage source [latex]V_1[/latex] at a
frequency which causes resonance with a current of I . The phasor diagram which is applicable to this circuit is
solution: At resonance, [latex]X_L=X_C [/latex] So,  [latex]Z=R_A+R_B [/latex] Therefore, input impedance in purely resistive, is minimum, and the input voltage and output current are in phase. So, [latex]V_1[/latex] and [latex]I[/latex] are in phase [latex]V_2=\frac{V_1}{R_A+R_B+j(X_L-X_C)}\times [R_B+j(X_L-X_C)] [/latex] But, [latex] X_L=X_C [/latex] [latex]V_2=\frac{V_1}{R_A+R_B} \times R_B [/latex] Therefore, [latex]V_2[/latex] is in phase with [latex]V_1[/latex] and [latex]V_2 \lt V_1[/latex] voltage across the capacitor [latex] V_C=I \times X_C=I \times \frac{1}{j\omega C} [/latex] [latex]V_C=\frac{1}{\omega C}\angle -90^{\circ}[/latex] So, [latex]V_C[/latex] lags the current by [latex]90^{\circ}.[/latex] The phasor diagram on the basis of above analysis.

question:
Question 147 The parameter type and the matrix representation of the relevant two port
parameters that describe the circuit shown are
solution: [latex]I_1=g_{11}V_1+g_{12}I_2 [/latex] [latex]V_2=g_{21}V_1+g_{22}I_2 [/latex] Since port-1 is open circuit, [latex]I_1=0[/latex] Port-2 is short-circuit, [latex]V_2=0 [/latex] [latex]g_{11}=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{I_1}{V_1} \end{matrix}\right|_{I_2=0}=\frac{0}{V_1}=0 [/latex] [latex]g_{12}=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{I_1}{I_2} \end{matrix}\right|_{V_1=0}=\frac{0}{I_2}=0 [/latex] [latex]g_{21}=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{V_2}{V_1} \end{matrix}\right|_{I_2=0}=\frac{0}{V_1}=0 [/latex] [latex]g_{22}=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{V_2}{I_1} \end{matrix}\right|_{V_1=0}=\frac{0}{I_2}=0[/latex] So, g-parameters, [latex]=\begin{bmatrix} g_{11} & g_{12}\\ g_{21}& g_{22} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question:
Question 148 In the circuit shown in the figure, the current source I=1A, the voltage source
V=5 V, [latex]R_{1}=R_{2}=R_{3}=1\Omega ,[/latex] [latex]L_{1}=L_{2}=L_{3}=1H,[/latex] [latex]C_{1}=C_{2}=1F[/latex] The currents (in A) through [latex]R_3[/latex] and through the voltage source V respectively will be
solution: In steady state, inductor behaves as short-circuit and capacitor behaves as open-circuit Voltage across, [latex]R_3=V=5V [/latex] Current through, [latex]R_3=I_1=\frac{V}{R_3}=\frac{5}{1}=5A[/latex] Apply KCL, [latex]-I+i_1-I_V=0 [/latex] Current through voltage source [latex]=I_V=I_1-1=5-1=4A[/latex]

question: Question 149 The parameters of the circuit shown in the figure are [latex]R_{i}=1M\Omega, R_{o}=10\Omega , A=10^{6}V/V[/latex]. If [latex]v_{i}=1 \mu V[/latex], then output voltage, input impedance and output impedance respectively are
solution: Output voltage [latex]V_0=AV_i[/latex] [latex] V_0=10^6 \times 1 \times 10^{-6}=1V [/latex] To calculate input impedance, [latex]V_{dc}[/latex] source is connected at input port Input impedance [latex]Z_i=\frac{V_{dc}}{I_i} [/latex] as loop is not closed, [latex]I_i=0[/latex] So,  [latex]Z_i=\frac{V_{dc}}{0}=\infty [/latex] To calculate output impedance, [latex]V_{dc}[/latex] source is connected at output port. Output impedance, [latex]Z_o=\frac{V_{dc}}{I_o}=\frac{I_oR_o+AV_i}{I_o} [/latex] As [latex]V_i=0 Z_o=R_o=10\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 150 In the figure the current source is [latex]1\angle 0[/latex] A, R=1[latex]\Omega[/latex], the impedances are [latex]Z_{C} =-j \Omega[/latex] and [latex]Z_{L}= 2j \Omega[/latex]. The Thevenin equivalent looking into the circuit across X-Y is
solution: To calculate Thevenin's impedance, current-souce is open-circuited [latex]Z_{th}=R+Z_L+Z_c[/latex] [latex] \;\;=1+2j-j [/latex] [latex]\;\;=1+j \Omega [/latex] Open-circuit voltage at terminals X-Y [latex]=I \times Z_{th} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=1\angle 0 \times (1+j) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\sqrt{2}\angle 15^{\circ} volts[/latex]

question:
Question 151 A coil of inductance 10 H and resistance 40 [latex]\Omega[/latex]  is connected as shown in the figure. After the switch S has been in contact ith point 1 for a very long time, it is moved to point 2 at, t=0. For the value of R=40[latex]\Omega[/latex], the time taken for 95% of the stored energy to
be dissipated is close to
solution: The circuit (in s-domain) [latex]I(s)=\frac{20}{(20+40+40)+10s} =\frac{20}{10s+100}=\frac{2}{s+10} [/latex] [latex]i(t)=L^{-1}[I(s)]=l^{-1}\left [ \frac{2}{s+10} \right ] =2e^{-10t} [/latex] [latex]i(t)=i_L(0^+)e^{-\frac{R_{eff}}{L}t} =2e^{-\frac{(20+40+40)}{10}t}=2e^{-10t} [/latex] Initial stored energy in inductor [latex] W_0=\frac{1}{2}Li^2_L(0^+) [/latex] [latex]\;\;\; \; =\frac{1}{2}\times 10 \times 2^2=20 Joules [/latex] Remaining energy in inductor [latex]W_1=0.05[/latex] [latex]W_0=0.05 \times 20=1 Joules [/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{2}Li^2_1=1 [/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{2}\times 10 \times i^2_1=1 [/latex] [latex]i_1=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}=0.4472A [/latex] [latex]i=2e^{-10T} [/latex] Let at [latex]t=T[/latex], current decrease to [latex]i_1[/latex] [latex] 0.4472=2e^{-10T} [/latex] [latex]T\approx 0.15sec[/latex]

question: Question 152 A coil of inductance 10 H and resistance 40 [latex]\Omega[/latex]  is connected as shown in the figure. After the switch S has been in contact ith point 1 for a very long time, it is moved to point 2 at, t=0. If, at t = [latex]0^{+}[/latex], the voltage across the coil is 120 V, the value of resistance R is
solution: Before moving the switch at [latex]t=0^-[/latex] The circuit is in steady state and inductor behaves as short-circuit. The circuit at [latex]t=0^-[/latex] [latex]i_L(0^-)=\frac{120}{20+40}=2A[/latex] After moving the switch at [latex]t=0^+[/latex] Current through inductor can not change abruptly. So, [latex]i_L(0^-)=i_L(0^+)=2A[/latex] [latex]V_L=i_L(0^+)\times (20+R) 120= 2 \times (20+R) R=40\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 153 Two networks are connected in cascade as shown in the figure. With usual
notations the equivalent A,B,C and D constants are obtained. Given that,
C = 0.025[latex]\angle 45^{\circ}[/latex], the value of [latex]Z_{2}[/latex] is

question:
Question 154 In the given figure, the Thevenin's equivalent pair (voltage, impedance), as seen
at the terminals P-Q, is given by
solution: To calculate [latex]R_{th}[/latex] (seen at terminals P-Q), voltage source is short-circuit [latex]V_{th}[/latex] = open-circuit voltage at terminals P-Q. [latex]V_{th}=\frac{4}{10+10}\times 10=2 V[/latex] Thevenin's equivalent circuit

question:
Question 155 The circuit shown in the figure is in steady state, when the switch is closed at
t = 0. Assuming that the inductance is ideal, the current through the inductor at
t = [latex]0^{+}[/latex] equals
solution: Before closing the switch, at [latex]t=0^-[/latex], the circuit is in steady state. So, inductor behaves as short-circuit [latex]i_L(0^-)=\frac{10}{10}=1A[/latex] After closing the switch, at [latex]t=0^+[/latex] Current through inductor can not change abruptly. [latex]\therefore \;\; i_L(0^+)=i_L(0^-)=1A[/latex]

question:
Question 156 For the three-phase circuit shown in the figure, the ratio of the currents [latex]I_{R}[/latex]: [latex]I_{Y}[/latex]: [latex]I_{B}[/latex]
is given by
solution:
Assuming phase sequence to be RYB Taking [latex]V_{RY}[/latex] as the reference, [latex]V_{RY}=V\angle 0^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]V_{YB}=V\angle -120^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]V_{BR}=V\angle -240^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]I_R=\frac{V_{RB}}{R_1}=-\frac{V_{BR}}{R_1} =-\frac{V\angle -240^{\circ}}{R_1}=\frac{V}{R_1}\angle -60^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] I_Y=\frac{V_{YB}}{R_1} 
 =-\frac{V\angle -120^{\circ}}{R_1} [/latex] Using KCL, [latex]I_R+I_Y+I_B=0 [/latex] [latex]\frac{V}{R_1}\angle -60^{\circ}+\frac{V}{R_1}\angle -120^{\circ} I_B=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_B=\sqrt{3}\frac{V}{R_1}\angle 90^{\circ} [/latex] So,  [latex] I_R:I_Y:I_B=\frac{V}{R_1}:\frac{V}{R_1}:\sqrt{3}\frac{V}{R_1}[/latex] [latex]\;\;\; =1:1:\sqrt{3}[/latex]

question:
Question 157 The RL circuit of the figure is fed from a constant magnitude, variable
frequency sinusoidal voltage source [latex]V_{IN}[/latex]. At 100 Hz, the R and L elements each
have a voltage drop [latex]\mu _{RMS}[/latex]. If the frequency of the source is changed to 50 Hz,
then new voltage drop across R is
solution: At f = 100Hz [latex]|V_R|=|V_L| [/latex] as R and L are series connected, current through R and L is same, so [latex]\begin{aligned}IR&=IX_L=I\omega L  \\ \Rightarrow \; R&=X_L=\omega L  \\ I&=\frac{V_{in}}{\sqrt{R^2+X_L^2}}  \\ &=\frac{V_{in}}{\sqrt{R^2+R^2}}=\frac{V_{in}}{\sqrt{2}R}  \\ V_R&=u_{rms}=IR  \\ V_R&=\left ( \frac{V_{in}}{\sqrt{2}R} \right ) \times R=\frac{V_{in}}{\sqrt{2}}  \\ V_{in}&=\sqrt{2}u_{rms}\;\;...(i)  \\  f&=50 Hz  \\ X_l & \propto f \\ \text{So, }  X'_L&=X_L \times \frac{50}{100} \\ &=\frac{X_L}{2}=\frac{R}{2}  \\ I'&=\frac{V_{in}}{\sqrt{R^2+(X'_L)^2}}  \\ &=\frac{V_{in}}{\sqrt{R^2+\left ( \frac{R}{2} \right )^2}}  \\ &=\frac{2V_{in}}{\sqrt{5}R}  \\ V'_R&=I'R \\ &=\left ( \frac{2V_{in}}{\sqrt{5}R} \right )R  \\ &=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}V_{in} \\  &\text{From equation (i), }\\ V'_R&=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} \times (\sqrt{2}u_{rms}) \\  &=\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{5}}u_{rms}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{5}}u_{rms}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 158 In the figure given, the initial capacitor voltage is zero. The switch is closed at t = 0. The final steady-state voltage across the capacitor is
solution: At [latex](t\rightarrow 0^+)[/latex]. The capacitor act as short-circuit. At [latex](t\rightarrow \infty )[/latex], the capacitor will become open circuit. Therefore, voltage across capacitor [latex]=\frac{20}{10+10}\times 10=10V[/latex]

question: Question 159 For the two port network shown in the figure, the Z-matrix is given by
solution: [latex]v_1=(i_1+i_2)Z_1  =Z_1i_1+Z_1i_2 [/latex] [latex]v_2=Z_2i_1+Z_1(i_1+i_2) =Z_1i_1+(Z_1+Z_2)i_2 [/latex] From above, we can write, [latex]\text{Z-matrix}=\begin{bmatrix} Z_1 &Z_1 \\ Z_1 & Z_1+Z_2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question: Question 160 The RMS value of the voltage u(t)= 3 + 4 cos (3t) is
solution: R.M.S. value of d.c voltage [latex]=V_{dc}^{(rms)}=3V[/latex] R.M.S. value of a.c. voltage [latex]=V_{ac}^{(rms)}=\left ( \frac{4}{\sqrt{2}} \right ) V[/latex] Therefore, R.M.S. value of the voltage [latex]\sqrt{3^2+\left ( \frac{4}{\sqrt{2}} \right )^2}[/latex] [latex]=\sqrt{9+8}=\sqrt{17}V[/latex]

question: Question 161 In the figure given below the value of R is
solution: The resultant (R) when viewed from voltage source [latex]=\frac{100}{8}=12.5 [/latex] [latex]R+10||10=12.5\Omega [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; R=12.5-10||10 =12.5-5=7.5\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 162 The Z-matrix of a 2-port network as given by [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 0.9 & 0.2\\ 0.2 & 0.6 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The element [latex]Y_{22}[/latex] of the corresponding Y-matrix of the same network is given by
solution: [latex][z]=\begin{bmatrix} 0.9 & 0.2\\ 0.2 & 0.6 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex][y]=[z]^{-1}=\frac{\begin{bmatrix} 0.6 & -0.2\\ -0.2 & 0.9 \end{bmatrix}}{[0.9 \times 0.6 -0.04]} =\begin{bmatrix} 1.2 & -0.4\\ -0.4 & 1.8 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]y_{22}=1.8[/latex]

question:
Question 163 The rms value of the resultant current in a wire which carries a dc current of 10
A and a sinusoidal alternating current of peak value 20 A is
solution: R.M.S value of d.c current [latex]=10A=I_{dc}[/latex] R.M.S. value of sinusoidal current [latex]=\left ( \frac{20}{\sqrt{2}} \right )A=I_{ac}[/latex] R.M.S. value of resultant, [latex]I_R=\sqrt{I_{ds}^2+I_{ac}^2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\sqrt{10^2+\left ( \frac{20}{\sqrt{2}} \right )^2}=17.32A[/latex]

question:
Question 164 In figure, the capacitor initially has a charge of 10 Coulomb. The current in the
circuit one second after the switch S is closed will be
solution: Using KVL, [latex]\begin{aligned} 100&=R\frac{dq}{dt}+\frac{q}{C} \\ 100C &= RC\frac{dq}{dt}+q  \\ \int_{q_0}^{q}\frac{dq}{100C-q}&=\frac{1}{RC}\int_{0}^{t}dt \\ 100C-q&=(100C-q_0)e^{-t/RC} \\ i=\frac{dq}{dt}&=\frac{100C-q_0}{RC}e^{-t/RC}\\ e^{-t/RC}&=40e^{-1}=14.7A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 165 In figure, the value of resistance R in [latex]\Omega[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\frac{V_P-100}{10}+\frac{V_P}{10}+2=0 [/latex] [latex]2V_P-100+20=0[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\; V_P=40V [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; R=\frac{V_P}{2}=\frac{40}{2}=20\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 166 In figure, the admittance values of the elements in Siemens are [latex]Y_{R}[/latex] = 0.5 + j0, [latex]Y_{L}[/latex] = 0 - j1.5, [latex]Y_{C}[/latex] = 0 + j0.3 respectively. The value of I as a
phasor when the voltage E across the elements is 10[latex]\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex]
 V is
solution: [latex]I_R=Y_RE[/latex] [latex]\;\;=(0.5+j0) \times 10\angle 0^{\circ}=5A [/latex] [latex]I_Y=Y_LE[/latex] [latex]\;\;=(0-j1.5)\times 10\angle 0^{\circ}=-j15A [/latex] [latex]I_C=Y_CE[/latex] [latex]\;\;=(0+j0.3)\times 10\angle 0^{\circ}=j3A [/latex] [latex]I=I_R+I_Y+I_C [/latex] [latex]\;\;=5+(-j15)+j3 \;\;=5-j12 A[/latex]

question: Question 167 In figure, [latex]R_{a}[/latex], [latex]R_{b}[/latex] and [latex]R_{c}[/latex] are [latex]20\Omega[/latex], [latex]10\Omega[/latex] and [latex]10\Omega[/latex] respectively. The resistances [latex]R_{1},R_{2}[/latex] and [latex]R_{3}[/latex] in [latex]\Omega[/latex] of an equivalent star-connection are
solution: Given : [latex]R-a=20\Omega R_b=10\Omega [/latex] and  [latex] R_c=10\Omega[/latex] [latex] R_1=\frac{R_bR_c}{R_a+R_b+R_c} =\frac{10 \times 10}{20+10+10}=2.5\Omega [/latex] [latex]R_2=\frac{R_cR_a}{R_a+R_b+R_c} =\frac{10 \times 20}{20+10+10}=5\Omega [/latex] [latex]R_3=\frac{R_aR_b}{R_a+R_b+R_c}=\frac{20 \times 10}{20+10+10}=5\Omega[/latex] Remember: If all the branches of [latex]\Delta[/latex]-connection has same impedance Z, then impedance of branch of Y-connection be Z/3.

question: Question 168 In figure, the value of the source voltage is
solution: Method-1: Using KCL, [latex]\frac{V_a-E}{6}+\frac{V_a}{6}+1=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; 2V-a-E=6\;\;...(i) [/latex] Where, [latex]\frac{E-V_a}{6}=2 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; E-V_a=12\;\;...(ii)[/latex] Solving equation (i)and (ii), we get [latex]V_a=18V[/latex] and [latex]E=30V[/latex] Method-2: I=2+1=3A Applying KVL in second loop, E=2x6+3x6=30V

question:
Question 169 The value of Z in figure, which is most appropriate to cause parallel resonance
at 500 Hz is
solution: Atresonance, the circuit should be in unity power factor. Hence, 'Z' should be capacitive. Admittance of the parallel circuit. [latex]Y=\frac{1}{jL\omega }+\frac{1}{1/jC\omega }=0 [/latex] [latex]\frac{-1}{L\omega }+C\omega =0 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; C=\frac{1}{L\omega ^2}=\frac{1}{2(2 \pi \times 500)^2} =0.05\mu F[/latex]

question: Question 170 The h-parameters for a two-port network are defined by [latex]\begin{bmatrix} E_{1}\\ I_{2} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} h_{11} & h_{12}\\ h_{21}&h_{22} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} I_{1}\\ E_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. For the two-port network shown in figure, the value of [latex]h_{12}[/latex] is given by
solution: [latex]h_{12}=\frac{E_1}{E_2}|_{I_1=0}[/latex] [latex] h_{12}[/latex]  is ratio of [latex]E_1 \; to \; E_2[/latex] for the input open-circuited condition. Assuming [latex]I_1=0[/latex] [latex]I_2=\frac{E_2}{2+(2+4)||4}=\frac{E_2}{4}[/latex] [latex] I_x=\frac{I_2}{(2+2)+4 }\times 4 =\frac{I_2}{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{E_2}{4} \right )=\frac{E_2}{8} [/latex] [latex]E_1=2I_x=2\frac{E_2}{8}=\frac{E_2}{4} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; \frac{E_1}{E_2}=0.25[/latex]

question:
Question 171 In the circuit shown in figure, the switch S is closed at time (t=0). The
voltage across the inductance at t=[latex]0^{+}[/latex], is
solution: Before closing the switch, the circuit was not energized, therefore, current through inductor and voltage across capacitor are zero. After closing the switch, at [latex]t=0^+[/latex] inductor acts as open-circuit and capacitor acts as shortc ircuit. Equivalent circuit at [latex]t=0^+[/latex] [latex]I=\frac{10}{3+4||4}=2A [/latex] [latex]V_L(0^+)I \times (4||4) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=2 \times 2=4V[/latex]

question: Question 172 In figure, the value of R is
solution: By KCL, [latex]\frac{V_P-40}{1}+\frac{V_P-100}{14}+\frac{V_P}{2}=0 [/latex] [latex]22V_P=660 [/latex] [latex]V_P=30V[/latex] Potential difference between node x and y =60V By taking KCL at node y [latex]-I-5+\frac{40-30}{1}=0 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; I= 5A  [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;  I=\frac{60}{5}=12\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 173 Two ac sources feed a common variable resistive load as shown in figure.
Under the maximum power transfer condition, the power absorbed by the load
resistance [latex]R_{L}[/latex] is
solution: For obtaining power absorbed by [latex]R_L[/latex] under maximum power transfer condition. We find thevenin's equivalent circuit across [latex]R_L[/latex]. [latex]Z_{th}[/latex] is calculated by short-circuting the voltage source. [latex]Z_{th}=(6+j8)||(6+j8)=3+j4\Omega[/latex] [latex]\frac{V_{th}-110\angle 0^{\circ}}{6+j8}+\frac{V_{th}-90\angle 0^{\circ}}{6+j8}=0 [/latex] [latex]V_{th}=100\angle 0^{\circ}V[/latex] For maximum power transfer , [latex]R_L=\sqrt{R_{th}^2+X_{th}^2}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\sqrt{3^2+4^2}=5\Omega[/latex] [latex] I=\frac{V_{th}}{(3+j4)+R_L}=\frac{100}{8+j4}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=11.18\angle -26.56^{\circ}A [/latex] Power absorbed by [latex]R_L (max)[/latex] [latex]\; =I^2R_L=11.18^2 \times 5[/latex] [latex]\;\;=625W[/latex]

question: Question 174 In figure, the potential difference between points P and Q is
solution: Given: [latex]V_R=10 V[/latex] By KCL, [latex]\frac{V_P-10}{2}+2+\frac{V_P}{8}=0 \;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]\frac{V_Q-10}{4}-2+\frac{V_Q}{6}=0 \;\;...(ii) [/latex] From equation (i), [latex]4(V_P-10)+2 \times 8 +V_P=0 [/latex] [latex]4V_P-40+16+V_P=0 [/latex] [latex]5V_P-24=0 [/latex] [latex]V_P=4.8 [/latex] From equation (ii), [latex]6(V_Q-10)-2 \times 4 \times 6 +4V_Q=0 [/latex] [latex]10V_Q-108=0 [/latex] [latex]V_Q=10.8 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;\; V_P-V_Q=-6V[/latex]

question:
Question 175 In the circuit of figure, the magnitudes of [latex]V_{L}[/latex] and [latex]V_{C}[/latex] are twice that of [latex]V_{R}[/latex]. Given
that f = 50 Hz, the inductance of the coil is
solution: [latex]V=V_R+i(V_L-V_C) [/latex] Since, [latex] |V_L|=|V_C| [/latex] and [latex] |V_L|=2|V_R|[/latex] Therefore, the circuit is at resonance and [latex]V_R=V[/latex] Quality factor [latex]=\frac{V_L}{V}=\frac{V_L}{V_R}=\frac{2V_R}{V_R}=2[/latex] As we know, [latex]Q=\frac{\omega _0L}{R} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; 2=\frac{2 \pi f \times L}{5} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;L=31.8mH[/latex]

question:
Question 176 In the figure, [latex]Z_{1}=10\angle -60 ^{\circ} , Z_{2}=10\angle 60^{\circ} , Z_{3}=50\angle 53.13^{\circ}[/latex]. The venin impedance
seen form X-Y is
solution: By Thevenin's theorem [latex]Z_{Th}=Z_{X-Y}=Z_1||Z_2+Z_3 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{Z_1 \times Z_2}{Z_1+Z_2}+Z_3 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{10\angle -60 \times 10\angle 60}{10\angle -60 + 10\angle 60}+50\angle 53.13 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=56.66\angle 45^{\circ}\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 177 A segment of a circuit is shown in figure. [latex]V_{R}[/latex] = 5V, [latex]V_{C}[/latex] = [latex]4 \sin 2t[/latex]. The voltage [latex]V_{L}[/latex] is
given by
solution: By KCL, [latex]I_P+I_Q+I_C+I_L=0[/latex] [latex] 2+2+I_C+I_L=0 [/latex] But,  [latex]I_C=C \times \frac{dv}{dt} [/latex] [latex]\;\; =1 \times \frac{d}{dt}(4 \sin 2t) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=(8 \cos 2t) [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; I_L=-(2+1+8 \cos 2t) [/latex] [latex]\;\; \;\;=-3-8 \cos 2t [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_L=L\left ( \frac{di}{dt} \right )[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=2 \times 2 \times 8 \sin 2t [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=32 \sin 2t[/latex] NOTE: KCL is based on the law of conservation of charges.

question:
Question 178 Figure Shows the waveform of the current passing through an inductor of
resistance [latex]1\Omega[/latex] and inductance 2 H. The energy absorbed by the inductor in the first four seconds is
solution: For [latex]0 \lt t \lt 2s[/latex] current varies linearly with time and given as [latex]i(t)=3t[/latex] and for [latex]2s \lt t \lt 4s[/latex] current is constant, [latex]i(t)=6A[/latex]. The energy absorbed by the inductor (Resistance neglected) in the first 2 sec, [latex]E_L=\int_{0}^{T}Li\frac{di}{dt}=E_{L_1}+E_{L_2} [/latex] [latex]E_{L_1}=\int_{0}^{2}Li \left (\frac{di}{dt} \right )dt [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\int_{0}^{2} 2 \times 3t \times 3\; dt [/latex] [latex]\;\;=18\int_{0}^{2}t\; dt [/latex] [latex]\;\;=18 \times \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{t^2}{2} \end{matrix}\right|^2_0 [/latex] [latex]\;\;= 18 \times \left [ \frac{4}{2}-0 \right ]=36J [/latex] The energy absorbed by the inductor in ([latex]2\rightarrow 4[/latex]) second [latex]E_{L_2}=\int_{2}^{4}Li\left ( \frac{di}{dt}dt \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{2}{4}2 \times 6 \times 0 \;dt=0 J[/latex] A pure indictor does not dissipate enegy but only stores it. Due to resistance, some energy is dissipated in the resistor. Therefore, total energy stored in the inductor and the energy dissipated in the resistor. The energy dissipated by the resistance in 4 sec. [latex]E_R=\int_{0}^{T}i^2 R\;dt [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\int_{0}^{2}(3t)^2 \times 1 \;dt+\int_{2}^{4}6^2 \times 1 \; dt[/latex] [latex] \;\;=9\int_{0}^{2}t^2\;dt +36\int_{2}^{4}1 \; dt [/latex] [latex]\;\;=9 \times \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{t^3}{3} \end{matrix}\right|_0^2+36t|_2^4[/latex] [latex] \;\;=9 \times \left ( \frac{8}{3} \right )+36 \times 2 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=24+72=96J[/latex] The total energy absorbed by the inductor in 4 sec [latex] =96 J +36 J =132 J[/latex]

question:
Question 179 In the circuit shown in figure, the switch is closed at time t=0.
The steady state value of the voltage [latex]V_c[/latex] is

Question 180 Consider the circuit shown in figure. If the frequency of the source is 50 Hz,
then a value of [latex]t_{0}[/latex] which results in a transient free response is
solution: For transient free response, [latex]\tan(\omega t_0)=\frac{\omega L}{R} [/latex] [latex]\tan(2 \pi \times 50 \times t_0)=\frac{2 \pi \times 50 \times 0.01}{5} [/latex] [latex]2 \pi \times 50 \times t_0=\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{\pi}{5} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=32.14^{\circ}=0.561 rad [/latex] [latex]t_0=\frac{0.561}{100 \pi}=1.786ms[/latex]

question:
Question 181 In the circuit shown in figure, it is found that the input ac voltage [latex]\left ( V_{i} \right )[/latex]  and current i are in phase. The coupling coefficient is [latex]K=\frac{M}{\sqrt{L_{1}L_{2}}}[/latex], where M is the mutual inductance between the two coils. The value of K and the dot polarity of
the coil P-Q are
solution: Input ac voltage and current will be in phase only at resonance condition, i.e. [latex]X_C=X_L [/latex] [latex]|-j12|=|j8+j8+2k\sqrt{(j8)\times (j8)}|[/latex] [latex] 12=8+8+16k [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; k=-\frac{4}{16}=-0.25[/latex] Hence, coupling will be opposite. Therefore, Dot will be at Q.

question:
Question 182 An 11 V pulse of 10 [latex]\mu s[/latex] duration is applied to the circuit shown in figure.
Assuming that the capacitor is completely discharged prior to applying the pulse,
the peak value of the capacitor voltage is
solution:
[latex]V_c(t)=V_c(\infty )-[V_c(\infty )-V_c(0 )]e^{-t/RC} [/latex] [latex]V_c(peak)=10-(10-0)e^{\frac{10 \times 10^{-6}}{\frac{10}{11} \times 10^3 \times 11 \times 10^{-9}}} 
 =10(1-e^{-1})=6.32V[/latex] [latex] (Where \;\;R_{net}=10||1=\frac{10}{11}k\Omega ) [/latex] [latex]V_c(\infty )=11 \times \frac{10}{10+1}=10V [/latex] and [latex]\because[/latex] pulse of duration [latex]10\mu s[/latex] is applies. Hence, capacitor charges till [latex]10\mu s[/latex]  and then starts discharging, so [latex]V_c[/latex] will be maximum at [latex]t=10\mu s[/latex].

question: Question 183 A series R-L-C circuit has R=[latex]50\Omega[/latex], L=[latex]100\mu [/latex] and C=[latex]1\mu[/latex]. The lower half power frequency of the circuit is
solution: [latex]\omega _0=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{\sqrt{100 \times 10^{-6} \times 10^{-6}}}=10^5 r/s [/latex] [latex]\Delta \omega =\frac{R}{L}=\frac{50}{100 \times 10^{-6}}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=50 \times 10^4 r/s [/latex] [latex]\omega _{lower}=\left [ \sqrt{\omega _0^2+\left ( \frac{\Delta \omega }{2} \right )^2}- \frac{\Delta \omega }{2}\right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\left [ \sqrt{(10^5)^2+\left ( \frac{5 \times 10^5}{2} \right )^2}-\frac{5 \times 10^5}{2} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=10^5\left [ \sqrt{1+6.25}-2.5 \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=0.193 \times 10^5 r/s [/latex] Hence, [latex] f_{lower}=\frac{\omega _{lower}}{2 \pi}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{0.193 \times 10^5}{2 \pi} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=3065 Hz\approx 3.055kHz[/latex]

question:
Question 184 A first order, low pass filter is given with R=50 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and C=[latex]5\mu F[/latex]. What is the
frequency at which the gain of the voltage transfer function of the filter is 0.25?
solution: [latex]T.F.=\frac{V_o}{V_i}=\frac{\frac{1}{j\omega C}}{R+\frac{1}{j\omega C}}[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{1}{1+j\omega CR} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \; |Gain|=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+(\omega CR)^2}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;0.25=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+(\omega \times 5 \times 10^{-6} \times 50)^2}} [/latex] On solving, [latex]\omega =15.49 \times 10^3 r/s [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; f=\frac{15.49}{2 \pi}=2.46 kHz[/latex]

question:
Question 185 In the circuit shown in figure, what value of C will cause a unity power factor at
the ac source?
solution: [latex]Y=j\omega C+\frac{1}{30\angle 40^{\circ}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=j\omega C+0.0255-j0.0214 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=0.0255+j(\omega C-0.0214) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=Real(Y)+k Img(Y) [/latex] To have unity power factor at ac source i.e. resonance condition, [latex]Img(Y)=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\omega C-0.0214=0 [/latex] [latex]\because \; \omega =2 \pi \times 50[/latex] [latex] \therefore \; C=\frac{0.0214}{100 \pi}=68.1\mu F[/latex]

question: Question 186 A two port network, shown in figure is described by the following equations [latex]I_1=Y_{11}E_1+Y_{12}E_2[/latex] [latex]I_2=Y_{21}E_1+Y_{22}E_2[/latex] The admittance parameters [latex]Y_{11}, Y_{12},Y_{21},Y_{22}[/latex] for the network shown are
solution: Using KVL, [latex]E_1=2I_1+2(I_1+I_2) [/latex] Again using KVL, [latex]E_2=2I_2+2(I_1+I_2) [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; [z]=\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 2\\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex] [y]=[z]^{-1} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{(4 \times 4 )-(2 \times 2)}\begin{bmatrix} 4 & -2\\ -2 & 4 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] [latex]\begin{bmatrix} Y_{11} & Y_{12}\\ Y_{21} & Y_{22} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & -1/6\\ -1/6 & 1/3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

options.A: 0.5 mho, 1 mho, 2 mho and 1 mho respectively
options.B: 1/3 mho, -1/6 mho, -1/6 mho and 1/3 mho respectively
options.C: 0.5 mho, 0.5 mho, 1.5 mho and 2 mho respectively
options.D: -2/5 mho, -3/7 mho, 3/7 mho and 2/5 mho respectively

Question 187 The graph of an electrical network has N nodes and B branches. The number of
links, L, with respect to the choice of a tree, is given by
solution: Number of links =B-(N-1) =B-N+1

Question 189 Consider the star network shown in figure. The resistance between terminals A
and B with terminal C open is [latex]6\Omega[/latex], between terminals B and C with terminal A open is [latex]11\Omega[/latex], and between terminals C and A with terminal B open is [latex]9\Omega[/latex]. Then
solution: When C is open, [latex]R_{AB}=R_A+R_B=6\Omega[/latex] When B is open, [latex]R_{AC}=R_A+R_C=9\Omega[/latex] When A is open, [latex]R_{BC}=R_B+R_C=11\Omega[/latex] On solving the above equations [latex]R_A=2\Omega ,R_B=4\Omega[/latex] and [latex]R_C=7\Omega[/latex]

Question 191 A passive 2-port network is in a steady-state. Compared to its input, the steady
state output can never offer

question: Question 192 Given two coupled inductors [latex]L_{1}[/latex] and [latex]L_{2}[/latex], their mutual inductance M satisfies
solution: [latex]M=K\sqrt{L_1L_2} [/latex] where , K= coefficient of coupling [latex]\because \; 0 \lt K \lt 1 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \; M \leq \sqrt{L_1L_2}[/latex]

question:
Question 193 A unit step voltage is applied at t = 0 to a series RL circuit with zero initial
conditions.
solution: At [latex]t=0^+[/latex] inductor works as open circuit. Hence, complete source voltage drops across it and consequently, current through the resistor R is zero. Hence, voltage across the resistor at [latex]t=0^+[/latex] is zero. And further with time it rises accroding to [latex]V_R(t)=(1-e^{-Rt/L})u(t)[/latex].

options.A: It is possible for the current to be oscillatory.
options.B: The voltage across the resistor at t = [latex]0^{+}[/latex] is zero.
options.C: The energy stored in the inductor in the steady state is zero.
options.D: The resistor current eventually falls to zero.

question:
Question 194 Two incandescent light bulbs of 40 W and 60 W rating are connected in series
across the mains. Then
solution: [latex]\because \;\;P\propto \frac{1}{R}[/latex] Therefore , resistance of 40 W bulb [latex]\gt[/latex] resistance of 60 W bulb. For series connection, current through both the bulbs will be same [latex]P=I^2R[/latex] (for series connection). Power consumed by 40 W bulb [latex]\gt[/latex]Power consumed by 60 W bulb. Hencem the 40 W bulb glows brighter.

question:
Question 195 In a series RLC circuit at resonance, the magnitude of the voltage developed
across the capacitor
solution: In a series RLC circuit, at resonance [latex]V_L=jQV_{source} [/latex] and  [latex] V_c=-jQV_{source} [/latex] also for  [latex] Q \gt 1, |V_c| \gt |V_{source}|[/latex] Hence, option (C) is correct.

options.B: can never be greater than the input voltage
options.C:
can be greater than the input voltage, however, it is [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] out of phase with
the input voltage
options.D: can be greater than the input voltage, and is in phase with the input voltage.
